title: the most marginalised children across the world what hope for 2020
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Paddy Dowling, The Independent’s humanitarian photojournalist, looks back at his pictures and stories from across the world this yearCreated with Sketch.In photos: Most marginalised children across the world Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.David, 13, arrived in Uganda in July 2016 fleeing the civil war that broke out in South Sudan. He arrived with his mother and father and his eight brothers and sisters after two days of walking. He recalls seeing many dead bodies lining the sides of the tracks that led to Uganda’s northern border. The family were fearful of abduction by rebel groups or becoming caught in crossfire between the government and militia groups. David enjoyed school immensely in South Sudan but said his school had closed due to conflict. He attends Alaba School at Bidi Bidi Refugee Settlement. David dreams of a better life for his family.Sarah, 14, arrived to Kigeme refugee camp from DRC in 2012. Her parents, now unemployed in Rwanda, worked as rag traders. They made the decision to flee the fighting for the safety and relative calm of Rwanda. They were made to feel very welcome by the host community. Sarah is enrolled in class, three years behind where she should be, due to conflict, and she really enjoys her schooling. GS Gasaka school, run by Education Above All Foundation and UNHCR, is providing her the environment to allow her to dream one day of becoming an accountant so she can help her family live a better life.Nakato 19, was born and raised in Yumbe, Uganda. A graduate from Aruma High School, she has aspirations of becoming a journalist. She is actively involved in a movement called “Raise up and Talk” to help empower the younger generation to share their experiences and stories as a form of therapy, to help process the trauma from a life in conflict. Forestal, nine, is in second grade at Marescot School, Haiti. The school is funded through the partnership between non-profit buildOn Haiti, and Educate A Child (EAC), who have constructed 58 schools, as well as training 959 teachers. Forestal explains how she was given up by her father after the death of her mother. She now lives with her auntie as a “restavek” (child in domestic servitude) where she performs chores around the house for at least two hours a day including laundry, sweeping and mopping floors. She can only recall seeing her father once in her entire life. “It was only for one day, but it was really great, we had so much fun,” she says. Forestal hopes that she can see him again – but he lives and works in Port Au Prince, more than three hours away by car.Furaha, six, attends Buremba Primary School. She is a member of the Batwa “Pygmy” tribe, forced out of their native home in the Bwindi Forest to make way for a national park protected as a Unesco World Heritage Site. She lives in Kitahurira settlement camp, about 2.5km and a three-hour walk from her school. The construction of schools and training of teachers in remote areas of challenging geography ensures those hardest to reach have a right to education. Building Tomorrow Uganda through its partnership with Education Above All Foundation has enrolled 53,373 out-of-school children back into quality primary education in Uganda.Niyosenga,12, arrived from Kiyiri, DRC, in 2016. Her mother was killed in the fierce fighting which swept through towns and villages. She made the journey with her father and grandmother to the relative safe haven of Uganda to join the 1.2 million refugees. Niyosenga remained out of education in DRC until the age of nine as the long walk to school was too dangerous with roads closed by police or rebel militia.To help pay for Niyosenga’s school fees her father grows maize while her grandmother, 72, weaves baskets.Jasme, 10, is enrolled at a buildOn school in Perigny. Her two brothers and three sisters all attend the same school. Unlike the reported 300,000 restavek children that live away from their biological parents, Jasme lives with her family.Esperence, 10, goes to Perigny school. Seated on a bench at the end of a long dark corridor, overcome with emotion, he explains how he was given up by his biological parents at the age of eight. He now lives with his auntie and is a restavek child. The term restavek comes from the French rester avec, to stay with. Discussing the work around the house he has to complete as part of his daily chores, he explains: “I can never go out and play with my friends as my house family always call me back inside to do more jobs.”Yean, six, lives in Phnom Penh. Yean’s mother, a widow, feels helpless as she simply cannot earn enough to support her family. Today, Yean lives with her 80-year-old grandmother Khzm Men in Sensok 5, a settlement in the village of Kohmouta on the outskirts of Phnom Penh. The settlement was relocated from one of the capital’s inner city slums areas. Yean attends public school on the periphery of the settlement but due to the informal school fees system in Cambodia, she is forced to consider dropping out due to lack of funds. Yean is desperate to continue her education to fulfil her dreams of becoming a nurse, but without assistance her dreams seem out of reach.Charles, 16, lived with his mother and father in DRC. The Marekera family were forced to leave because their son was persecuted for being an albino. His father was repeatedly beaten after refusing to sell Charles to witchdoctors, who believe teeth, fingers and eyes brought good luck to those who bought their body parts. The transition for Charles arriving in Uganda from DRC has left him with large gaps in his education. Leaving as a senior in secondary school, he now finds himself back in primary school – and facing a similar stigma as an albino in Uganda. His long walks to school are interrupted by strangers attempting to lure him away to profit from the sale of his body parts. Charles explained: “I will never feel safe, however my safety now is less important to me than getting an education. I am determined to get my diploma and have a job where I can help protect the rights of other albinos.”Athar, 21, a beneficiary of Al Fakhoora, a programme of the Education Above All Foundation, was the youngest member to join the writers’ association, aged 14. She stressed the importance of explaining what is happening to the Palestinian people. Five years ago the conflict changed her life forever. She said: “The house was full of our relatives, suddenly everything went dark. I tried to get out of the house, I felt a pain in my leg and there was so much blood. I lost consciousness and woke in the ambulance. Hospitals ran out of anaesthetic so doctors stitched injuries I sustained without it, it was incredibly painful. I heard the news that my father was killed. Losing him was incredibly difficult for me as we were so close.” As a child, Athar had dreamt of becoming a writer or a poet. She said: “My father was my inspiration, encouraging me to write, since his death I have struggled to write anything. For me education is like food or fuel, an energy that gives me power to keep going.”Moza was born and raised east of the Tigris river that ides the city of Mosul. Her parents and five siblings have lived in a two-room concrete dwelling for 10 years. Farhan, Moza’s father, works as a labourer carrying blocks on construction sites across the city. He is in need of a hernia operation, which will cost £200, and finds work extremely difficult. He can’t afford six months off work to recover. The family income is only £62 per month, which barely covers bills. They are forced to take credit from shops to be able to eat. Moza is due to enrol back into schooling. However, at present, she cares for her mother who suffers respiratory problems due to a lodged bullet in her lung after being caught in crossfire during the conflict. She doesn’t know what to expect as she has never set foot in a classroom. Two years beyond the normal enrolment age of six, she still has great dreams of working with NGOs to help residents displaced from the city.Jonas, 12, was born in a village situated on the shores of Lake Victoria. He now lives with his father, a fisherman, and his step-mother a farmer. Jonas enrolled into an Educate A Child (EAC) and Graca Machel Trust (GMT) partnership in 2017. GMT conducted a survey reaching out to the community to help identify out-of-school children in the region. The survey identified more than 20,000. Jonas was one of those and set foot into a classroom for the first time at the age of 10. The mandatory age for school enrolment is seven, however his family’s lack of available funds meant he could not enrol into school. Also childhood illnesses, easily treated by relatively inexpensive medicines, meant he spent a huge part of his childhood unwell as his father could not afford treatment. When asked what it was like to take his first steps into a classroom, he replied: “It was incredibly exciting, and now it is even more exciting as there is a good chance I will go to secondary school.”Ali, nine, a Syrian refugee family from Deir ez-Zur district in eastern Syria arrived in Lebanon in 2011. They fled their home with several neighbours by bus toward a safer haven in Lebanon at the outbreak of civil war, which tore through their country. Heavy shelling bombarded their bus and the remainder of their journey had to be made on foot. Nine-year old Ali Ahmed’s father, an agricultural labourer explained that life in Lebanon was hard as they struggle to pay basic bills such as food and rent. As with most Syrian refugees, they are in debt to their landlords and to local shops owners. The collective family income is barely enough to cover any of their bills. Ali, one of the family’s 10 children, attends school 10km from home and dreams, one day, to be able to return home with his family to Syria.Chacha, 12, was born and raised in a small village in northwestern Tanzania, where he lives with his mother and two siblings. He has never set foot in a classroom and is one of a reported 1.89 million out-of-school children in the country today. Chacha works seven days per week scavenging gold mining sites, digging up rocks containing gold-residue. To avoid being captured or shot by mining and government police for trespass, he works under the cover of darkness, 6pm to 6am. The rocks he finds, he sells to middle men, for approximately £1.50 per shift, who crush them to extract the gold. He explained: “I have no choice, I know the work is dangerous but I feel I have to help provide for my family. It makes me sad not being able to go to school.” The money Chacha earns he uses to purchase clothes for himself and his siblings, the remainder he gives to his mother to contribute to food costs. When he returns home from his 12-hour shift, he tends to the family cattle.Owen, 16, has been enrolled in Buremba Primary School since 2007 and is one of eight siblings. Now in older years at school, he must pay more money. His parents are peasant farmers and work the land digging and picking tea, this means they must work most days to be able to keep up the payments. Buremba School is one of 60 new schools constructed under the Building Tomorrow and Educate A Child programme in Uganda.Afat, 12, left his home in Deir ez-Zor, Syria six years ago, forced out by the civil war which displaced millions of people, in his case to the Bekaa Valley, Lebanon. He is one of the thousands of Syrian refugee children sat in doorways of Lebanon’s many tents, shelters and makeshift homes dreaming of an education. Instead, he works 11 hours a day collecting scrap metal which he sells for around £2.50. He knows he has a right to education, but he is concerned to help provide for his family. He dreams of one day being able to return home to Syria with his family, to a better life.Mamoke, 10, has never been to school. Abandoned by her biological parents along with her eight siblings, she now lives with her grandmother in the village of Kuriyah. She grazes cattle six hours a day for her grandmother in return for her keep. She was registered for school but never enrolled. Her grandmother and  is unable to afford the voluntary parental contribution fees. Mamoke describes her household as poor, her grandmother unable to provide more than one meal per day for her. Mamoke added: “There are many days where we do not eat at all.” She dreams of becoming a teacher, if she was able to go to school, so she can help others in her current situation.Ikiriza, 5, Kamwenge District, Uganda. Ikiriza who is five years old lives in a small house with his nine brothers and sisters. His parents can’t afford school tuition fees for all the children, leaving Ikiriza with little choice but to fund his own education by working weekends carrying plastic jerry cans of water from the lake for various households of the neighbourhood in Kamwenge district. For this, he earns the equivalent of 5 US cents a day, which helps contribute towards his school fees at Bisozi Primary. He dreams of one day becoming a doctor so that he can help his father who suffers from ill health.Rami, six, lives at Beach Camp, on the sea front amongst the heart of the fishing community al-Shati in the northern Gaza Strip. Rami walks amongst the rubble of shelled buildings, a reminder of past and present conflicts. Restriction to employment and travel have meant many Palestinians are confined in Gaza. Some bright lights still shine as Rami attends grade P1 in school and dreams of becoming a footballer one day.Abdul 10, with his gaze to the floor, wrapped in blankets, huddles by the family stove. His father, Muhammad, emerges from the black of the adjoining room clutching an armful of medical documents written in French, a language he cannot read. His son is two years overdue a heart operation that would save his life. Srey, three, lives in a small dark room with her parents, siblings and relatives. A total of eight people live in a cramped, damp space in a makeshift barn of corrugated metal on the edge of the railroad tracks in the urban slums. The CYMCA Facility drop-in centre, funded in partnership between EAA and Aide et Action, provides emergency education to around 80 children in the area.Joender, six, from Maracaibo in Venezuela arrived in Ipiales, Colombia, after a 33-day journey mainly on foot. He is one of 3.5 million Venezuelan refugees that have left their homes following a catastrophic economic meltdown of his country leaving its citizens starving with no access to food, employment, medical services or education. He holds a packet of crackers, a kind donation from one of the many generous Colombians offering support to the Venezuelan people.Kennedy, 13, displaced to Uganda. He is another statistic of the 2.3 million South Sudanese refugees that fled the outbreak of civil war. Uganda alone shouldering 800,000 refugees. Kennedy was denied a normal childhood and instead became a witness to violence, torture and death in war. Not surprisingly, Kennedy’s family were unwilling to send him to school with threat of armed attack, abduction or recruitment by militias. On arrival in Uganda, Kennedy was still held back from attending school and fulfilling his dream of becoming a doctor. His parents were simply unable to afford the cost of a pair of shoes required for enrolment.“The canvas Billingham bags which carry the tools of my trade. They have sat beside me in the dust of countries around the world listening with me to every word of every story. I feel torn staring at them, joy at returning to my loved ones and the heartache of those I had to leave behind. Now they sit on the polished floor of my room, zipped up and lined up. I need them closer, to feel their weight on my shoulders again, I need to be away.….”David, 13, arrived in Uganda in July 2016 fleeing the civil war that broke out in South Sudan. He arrived with his mother and father and his eight brothers and sisters after two days of walking. He recalls seeing many dead bodies lining the sides of the tracks that led to Uganda’s northern border. The family were fearful of abduction by rebel groups or becoming caught in crossfire between the government and militia groups. David enjoyed school immensely in South Sudan but said his school had closed due to conflict. He attends Alaba School at Bidi Bidi Refugee Settlement. David dreams of a better life for his family.Sarah, 14, arrived to Kigeme refugee camp from DRC in 2012. Her parents, now unemployed in Rwanda, worked as rag traders. They made the decision to flee the fighting for the safety and relative calm of Rwanda. They were made to feel very welcome by the host community. Sarah is enrolled in class, three years behind where she should be, due to conflict, and she really enjoys her schooling. GS Gasaka school, run by Education Above All Foundation and UNHCR, is providing her the environment to allow her to dream one day of becoming an accountant so she can help her family live a better life.Nakato 19, was born and raised in Yumbe, Uganda. A graduate from Aruma High School, she has aspirations of becoming a journalist. She is actively involved in a movement called “Raise up and Talk” to help empower the younger generation to share their experiences and stories as a form of therapy, to help process the trauma from a life in conflict. Forestal, nine, is in second grade at Marescot School, Haiti. The school is funded through the partnership between non-profit buildOn Haiti, and Educate A Child (EAC), who have constructed 58 schools, as well as training 959 teachers. Forestal explains how she was given up by her father after the death of her mother. She now lives with her auntie as a “restavek” (child in domestic servitude) where she performs chores around the house for at least two hours a day including laundry, sweeping and mopping floors. She can only recall seeing her father once in her entire life. “It was only for one day, but it was really great, we had so much fun,” she says. Forestal hopes that she can see him again – but he lives and works in Port Au Prince, more than three hours away by car.Furaha, six, attends Buremba Primary School. She is a member of the Batwa “Pygmy” tribe, forced out of their native home in the Bwindi Forest to make way for a national park protected as a Unesco World Heritage Site. She lives in Kitahurira settlement camp, about 2.5km and a three-hour walk from her school. The construction of schools and training of teachers in remote areas of challenging geography ensures those hardest to reach have a right to education. Building Tomorrow Uganda through its partnership with Education Above All Foundation has enrolled 53,373 out-of-school children back into quality primary education in Uganda.Niyosenga,12, arrived from Kiyiri, DRC, in 2016. Her mother was killed in the fierce fighting which swept through towns and villages. She made the journey with her father and grandmother to the relative safe haven of Uganda to join the 1.2 million refugees. Niyosenga remained out of education in DRC until the age of nine as the long walk to school was too dangerous with roads closed by police or rebel militia.To help pay for Niyosenga’s school fees her father grows maize while her grandmother, 72, weaves baskets.Jasme, 10, is enrolled at a buildOn school in Perigny. Her two brothers and three sisters all attend the same school. Unlike the reported 300,000 restavek children that live away from their biological parents, Jasme lives with her family.Esperence, 10, goes to Perigny school. Seated on a bench at the end of a long dark corridor, overcome with emotion, he explains how he was given up by his biological parents at the age of eight. He now lives with his auntie and is a restavek child. The term restavek comes from the French rester avec, to stay with. Discussing the work around the house he has to complete as part of his daily chores, he explains: “I can never go out and play with my friends as my house family always call me back inside to do more jobs.”Yean, six, lives in Phnom Penh. Yean’s mother, a widow, feels helpless as she simply cannot earn enough to support her family. Today, Yean lives with her 80-year-old grandmother Khzm Men in Sensok 5, a settlement in the village of Kohmouta on the outskirts of Phnom Penh. The settlement was relocated from one of the capital’s inner city slums areas. Yean attends public school on the periphery of the settlement but due to the informal school fees system in Cambodia, she is forced to consider dropping out due to lack of funds. Yean is desperate to continue her education to fulfil her dreams of becoming a nurse, but without assistance her dreams seem out of reach.Charles, 16, lived with his mother and father in DRC. The Marekera family were forced to leave because their son was persecuted for being an albino. His father was repeatedly beaten after refusing to sell Charles to witchdoctors, who believe teeth, fingers and eyes brought good luck to those who bought their body parts. The transition for Charles arriving in Uganda from DRC has left him with large gaps in his education. Leaving as a senior in secondary school, he now finds himself back in primary school – and facing a similar stigma as an albino in Uganda. His long walks to school are interrupted by strangers attempting to lure him away to profit from the sale of his body parts. Charles explained: “I will never feel safe, however my safety now is less important to me than getting an education. I am determined to get my diploma and have a job where I can help protect the rights of other albinos.”Athar, 21, a beneficiary of Al Fakhoora, a programme of the Education Above All Foundation, was the youngest member to join the writers’ association, aged 14. She stressed the importance of explaining what is happening to the Palestinian people. Five years ago the conflict changed her life forever. She said: “The house was full of our relatives, suddenly everything went dark. I tried to get out of the house, I felt a pain in my leg and there was so much blood. I lost consciousness and woke in the ambulance. Hospitals ran out of anaesthetic so doctors stitched injuries I sustained without it, it was incredibly painful. I heard the news that my father was killed. Losing him was incredibly difficult for me as we were so close.” As a child, Athar had dreamt of becoming a writer or a poet. She said: “My father was my inspiration, encouraging me to write, since his death I have struggled to write anything. For me education is like food or fuel, an energy that gives me power to keep going.”Moza was born and raised east of the Tigris river that ides the city of Mosul. Her parents and five siblings have lived in a two-room concrete dwelling for 10 years. Farhan, Moza’s father, works as a labourer carrying blocks on construction sites across the city. He is in need of a hernia operation, which will cost £200, and finds work extremely difficult. He can’t afford six months off work to recover. The family income is only £62 per month, which barely covers bills. They are forced to take credit from shops to be able to eat. Moza is due to enrol back into schooling. However, at present, she cares for her mother who suffers respiratory problems due to a lodged bullet in her lung after being caught in crossfire during the conflict. She doesn’t know what to expect as she has never set foot in a classroom. Two years beyond the normal enrolment age of six, she still has great dreams of working with NGOs to help residents displaced from the city.Jonas, 12, was born in a village situated on the shores of Lake Victoria. He now lives with his father, a fisherman, and his step-mother a farmer. Jonas enrolled into an Educate A Child (EAC) and Graca Machel Trust (GMT) partnership in 2017. GMT conducted a survey reaching out to the community to help identify out-of-school children in the region. The survey identified more than 20,000. Jonas was one of those and set foot into a classroom for the first time at the age of 10. The mandatory age for school enrolment is seven, however his family’s lack of available funds meant he could not enrol into school. Also childhood illnesses, easily treated by relatively inexpensive medicines, meant he spent a huge part of his childhood unwell as his father could not afford treatment. When asked what it was like to take his first steps into a classroom, he replied: “It was incredibly exciting, and now it is even more exciting as there is a good chance I will go to secondary school.”Ali, nine, a Syrian refugee family from Deir ez-Zur district in eastern Syria arrived in Lebanon in 2011. They fled their home with several neighbours by bus toward a safer haven in Lebanon at the outbreak of civil war, which tore through their country. Heavy shelling bombarded their bus and the remainder of their journey had to be made on foot. Nine-year old Ali Ahmed’s father, an agricultural labourer explained that life in Lebanon was hard as they struggle to pay basic bills such as food and rent. As with most Syrian refugees, they are in debt to their landlords and to local shops owners. The collective family income is barely enough to cover any of their bills. Ali, one of the family’s 10 children, attends school 10km from home and dreams, one day, to be able to return home with his family to Syria.Chacha, 12, was born and raised in a small village in northwestern Tanzania, where he lives with his mother and two siblings. He has never set foot in a classroom and is one of a reported 1.89 million out-of-school children in the country today. Chacha works seven days per week scavenging gold mining sites, digging up rocks containing gold-residue. To avoid being captured or shot by mining and government police for trespass, he works under the cover of darkness, 6pm to 6am. The rocks he finds, he sells to middle men, for approximately £1.50 per shift, who crush them to extract the gold. He explained: “I have no choice, I know the work is dangerous but I feel I have to help provide for my family. It makes me sad not being able to go to school.” The money Chacha earns he uses to purchase clothes for himself and his siblings, the remainder he gives to his mother to contribute to food costs. When he returns home from his 12-hour shift, he tends to the family cattle.Owen, 16, has been enrolled in Buremba Primary School since 2007 and is one of eight siblings. Now in older years at school, he must pay more money. His parents are peasant farmers and work the land digging and picking tea, this means they must work most days to be able to keep up the payments. Buremba School is one of 60 new schools constructed under the Building Tomorrow and Educate A Child programme in Uganda.Afat, 12, left his home in Deir ez-Zor, Syria six years ago, forced out by the civil war which displaced millions of people, in his case to the Bekaa Valley, Lebanon. He is one of the thousands of Syrian refugee children sat in doorways of Lebanon’s many tents, shelters and makeshift homes dreaming of an education. Instead, he works 11 hours a day collecting scrap metal which he sells for around £2.50. He knows he has a right to education, but he is concerned to help provide for his family. He dreams of one day being able to return home to Syria with his family, to a better life.Mamoke, 10, has never been to school. Abandoned by her biological parents along with her eight siblings, she now lives with her grandmother in the village of Kuriyah. She grazes cattle six hours a day for her grandmother in return for her keep. She was registered for school but never enrolled. Her grandmother and  is unable to afford the voluntary parental contribution fees. Mamoke describes her household as poor, her grandmother unable to provide more than one meal per day for her. Mamoke added: “There are many days where we do not eat at all.” She dreams of becoming a teacher, if she was able to go to school, so she can help others in her current situation.Ikiriza, 5, Kamwenge District, Uganda. Ikiriza who is five years old lives in a small house with his nine brothers and sisters. His parents can’t afford school tuition fees for all the children, leaving Ikiriza with little choice but to fund his own education by working weekends carrying plastic jerry cans of water from the lake for various households of the neighbourhood in Kamwenge district. For this, he earns the equivalent of 5 US cents a day, which helps contribute towards his school fees at Bisozi Primary. He dreams of one day becoming a doctor so that he can help his father who suffers from ill health.Rami, six, lives at Beach Camp, on the sea front amongst the heart of the fishing community al-Shati in the northern Gaza Strip. Rami walks amongst the rubble of shelled buildings, a reminder of past and present conflicts. Restriction to employment and travel have meant many Palestinians are confined in Gaza. Some bright lights still shine as Rami attends grade P1 in school and dreams of becoming a footballer one day.Abdul 10, with his gaze to the floor, wrapped in blankets, huddles by the family stove. His father, Muhammad, emerges from the black of the adjoining room clutching an armful of medical documents written in French, a language he cannot read. His son is two years overdue a heart operation that would save his life. Srey, three, lives in a small dark room with her parents, siblings and relatives. A total of eight people live in a cramped, damp space in a makeshift barn of corrugated metal on the edge of the railroad tracks in the urban slums. The CYMCA Facility drop-in centre, funded in partnership between EAA and Aide et Action, provides emergency education to around 80 children in the area.Joender, six, from Maracaibo in Venezuela arrived in Ipiales, Colombia, after a 33-day journey mainly on foot. He is one of 3.5 million Venezuelan refugees that have left their homes following a catastrophic economic meltdown of his country leaving its citizens starving with no access to food, employment, medical services or education. He holds a packet of crackers, a kind donation from one of the many generous Colombians offering support to the Venezuelan people.Kennedy, 13, displaced to Uganda. He is another statistic of the 2.3 million South Sudanese refugees that fled the outbreak of civil war. Uganda alone shouldering 800,000 refugees. Kennedy was denied a normal childhood and instead became a witness to violence, torture and death in war. Not surprisingly, Kennedy’s family were unwilling to send him to school with threat of armed attack, abduction or recruitment by militias. On arrival in Uganda, Kennedy was still held back from attending school and fulfilling his dream of becoming a doctor. His parents were simply unable to afford the cost of a pair of shoes required for enrolment.“The canvas Billingham bags which carry the tools of my trade. They have sat beside me in the dust of countries around the world listening with me to every word of every story. I feel torn staring at them, joy at returning to my loved ones and the heartache of those I had to leave behind. Now they sit on the polished floor of my room, zipped up and lined up. I need them closer, to feel their weight on my shoulders again, I need to be away.….”As each year draws to a close, emotions you&nbsphave tried to control finally take grip. I feel torn – from the joy at returning to my&nbsploved ones and the heartache for those I&nbsphad to leave behind. I am staring at my canvas camera bags, which sat beside me in the dust of countries around the world.&nbspNow they sit on the polished floor of my room, zipped up. I need them closer, to feel their weight on my shoulders again, I need to be away…Here I have compiled a collection of photographs and memories, comprising the stories of some of the most marginalised children in the world.Winter: Abdul, a Syrian refugee aged 10, is seated in a makeshift shelter, perched high among&nbspthe rugged snowy mountain caps of Arsal, Lebanon. He holds his father’s hand as they both huddle&nbspby the stove for warmth. He has the haunting stare of a boy who knows he is&nbspgoing to die, an expression that cuts through the paraffin haze of the dark room as temperatures fall below zero. Mohammed, his father, gaunt from grief, explains&nbsphis son is two years overdue for an operation that could save his life.&nbspWith no means to finance it, he raises&nbsphis hands to the sky in hope that his prayers would be answered.&nbspI remember waiting to see my doctor as a child. I knew my turn would come Abdul knew his would not.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSpring:&nbspVenezuelan refugees who once ate together as families around their own tables&nbspnow eat from rubbish bins on their hands and knees to survive the crisis in their country. All the while, their president publicly feasts&nbspin lavish establishments. Roughly 3.5 million Venezuelans, among them doctors, lawyers and teachers, have left their country, out of starvation and fear.Joender, aged six, from Maracaibo in Venezuela, arrived in&nbspIpiales, Colombia, exhausted and hungry. He was offloaded with his family from a galvanised lorry like cattle, after a 33-day journey, mostly on foot, where they were forced to beg for food to survive. His cupped hands are&nbsprewarded with a packet of biscuits donated by a local in the town. He clutches&nbspthe packet like a prize. Having never begged for food myself as a child, I could not begin to understand the internal dialogue in doing so. I knew I could simply open a fridge door&nbspJoender&nbspcan’t.Summer:&nbspEsperence, aged 10, is a Haitian “restavek” or child slave. He was&nbspgiven away by his biological parents to a more affluent household and&nbspforced into a life of domestic servitude. The feeling of being abandoned proves&nbspto be too much for him. Standing in the kitchen and washing dishes, he simply shrugs his small shoulders, and one by one the tears roll&nbspdown his face. Hours each day are spent cleaning, sweeping and washing.&nbsp“I can never go out and play with my friends as my house family always call me back inside to do more jobs,”&nbsphe says.&nbspNearly 260 million children aren’t in school – do we care? Forced into a life of domestic servitude, Haiti’s child slavesThe global challenge to ensure all children can go to schoolThe importance of a solid work ethic was engrained into me at a young age. However, I remember the luxury of choice: I knew I could say no. Esperence knows he cannot.&nbspAutumn: Mamoke, aged 10, has never set foot in a classroom. Abandoned by her parents along with her siblings, she now lives with her grandmother at the mercy of abject poverty. In a dark room in remote north western Tanzania, she explains&nbsphow not going to school saddens&nbspher. But she nonetheless still dreams that somehow she could become a teacher to help others like her with no access to education. I didn't have a choice.&nbspI had to go to school. Mamoke didn’t have a choice, but that was because the right of education was unavailable to her. I realise I have taken so much&nbspfor granted in my life. Children around the world live with no access to healthcare, displaced from their home, going to sleep hungry, growing up in conflict and with no&nbspeducation.I did not choose my career any more than I chose my life. It chose me, and it is the greatest privilege, a blessing and a burden in the same breath. I&nbspwill continue to hold the world to account, hoping&nbspit will eventually force the changes that will create better choices for those who deserve them.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: struggling family universal credit sandwiches christmas dinner
story: Neil Campbell and Jo Holbrook-Morris, who both claim Universal Credit are living on just £ a week.The parents-of-two have said that financial pressures mean they wont be able to have a proper Christmas dinner this year.The family has put all its savings into a community farm project on Nunsthorpe Estate, Grimsby.But a hold up in a planning application to expand their farm has meant the couple have had to use their own money to keep the business up and running.In order to ensure their kids Olivia,  and Monty, , have gts on Christmas day, the family are preparing for a budget festive season without turkey or pigs in blankets.With  animals to feed, including donkeys, sheep, pigs, goats and chickens, as well as bills to pay, the family says it will be left eating sandwiches on Christmas day.Neil said: At the moment we are really struggling, we have put everything that we had into setting up the farm, but due to the delays that we have had with planning, we have been forced onto Universal Credit.The thing is, the community have really rallied around the farm and embraced it as their own, so we feel that we have to keep things going for them, in the hope that some day we can turn things around.Because we were initially told that our planning application would take just eight weeks, we were given assurances that we could invest in the farm, and then once we did, the application was delayed indefinitely, putting us where we are at the moment.I just hope that we can get this sorted soon, so that we can get the Nunnys Farm properly up and running.Jo said that while they have made sure that their kids have presents this Christmas, she and Neil will be going without anything, as they do not have the funds.The family has been claiming Universal Credit since June.Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.Jo said: Now we know what it is like to live on nothing, we have got used to going without.We have sold everything that we can possibly sell to keep ourselves going, but we just dont know how long we can last like this.At the minute, it looks like we will just be having sandwiches this Christmas, because we cant afford anything  after making sure that our kids have presents and are well cared for.This comes as another young family were forced into debt and had to rely on handouts after having a five-week wait to receive Universal Credit.A spokesperson for North East Lincolnshire Council said: We are in contact with Centre and have met a number of times to explain that we need to make up for the loss of the sports pitch.We have explained this position several times and what we’re doing to try and resolve it.The Council is supportive of the farm, and as landlord would be agreeable to the proposal.However, any sub-lease or change of use is subject to the necessary permissions and whilst we are doing our utmost to resolve the situation, there is a process to follow when someone wants to change the use of a sports field.We are working with Sport England to try to resolve this to allow their objection to the plans to be lted.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. Universal Credit claimants could have Christmas benefits slashed  bosses pay wages early this month.Meanwhile, a five-week wait for Universal credit payouts has pushed a young family into debt and forced them to rely on handouts.And with changes coming into force in  around how Universal Credit works - find out how they will affect your payments.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says football eradicate racism
story: Le bans for offenders. Close the stadium for a match — or at the very least the stand where the abuse came from.Racism at grounds was far worse in the past. But it has spiked again and can be wiped out with severe enough deterrents.We don’t buy, though, that these morons are emboldened by politicians.The Left seeks to blame Boris Johnson for everything.So they pretend his use of words like “piccaninnies”, in a  satirical attack on white leaders posing as colonial masters, was motivated by racism.No one who knows Boris thinks that of him.No one but the racists themselves are to blame for the Spurs outrage.Our leagues must stop wringing their hands and take forceful action.THE defiance of American death-crash driver Anne Sacoolas is outrageous.She accepts that she killed teenager Harry Dunn while driving on the wrong side of the road in the UK. But her lawyer says a prosecution and potential jail term is “not a proportionate response”.Britain is not a banana republic.Our justice system is as advanced as America’s. It is for our courts, not a suspect or her lawyer, to decide what is proportionate.Accidents can have consequences.Mrs Sacoolas will not want to leave her kids.Neither should she want them living with the knowledge their mum killed a young man and fled into hiding.Our Government must pursue extradition and the US must grant it — as we doubtless would were the roles reversed.ED Miliband won’t need long to diagnose the cause of four Labour election defeats in a row.He was behind three of them.Brown, the hapless oaf, lost in .Miliband then took the party to the left, gting the Tories their  winAnd Ed was just getting started.He sold party memberships for £ and the hard-Left piled in, made the toxic fool Corbyn leader and two more defeats followed.Who would now bet against a fth, given the new leadership candidates The latest, Islington snob Emily Thornberry, has a distaste for working-class people which is mutual — as White Van Man Dan Ware makes clear today.And in branding our PM — newly elected by million voters — a “feckless, lying charlatan”, Thornberry promises five more years of the same juvenile abuse putting millions off Labour.Not learning much, are they THREE years of furious political ision.Wasn’t it fantastic when it stopped To all Sun readers — Left or Right, Leavers or Remainers — have a fabulous Christmas! Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queens speech heal nation
story: The Queen — with her beloved husband in hospital — faced the cameras on Sunday with her usual stf upper lip as she attended a carol service at Sandringham.She was doing what she does best, getting on with things quietly but resolutely when it gets tough.And make no mistake, this year has been a second annus horribilis for the monarch.A year that began with the Duke of Edinburgh’s involvement in a car crash that left a motorist injured, ended with him being rushed to hospital by helicopter due to a pre-existing condition.She has also had to endure her favourite son Prince Andrew becoming so entwined in the Jeffrey Epstein scandal that it was in danger of damaging the monarchy itself.Then Prince Harry confirmed reports that he and Prince William had fallen out.One of the joys that Christmas brings for the Queen is it bringing the whole family together. But sadly the newest member, ArchieHarrison Mountbatten-Windsor, won’t be there.He will be with his parents Harry and Meghan somewhere in Canada, celebrating away from the royals.That’s a real shame, because with his upbeat presence Harry would have got the Queen laughing over the turkey.I watched the boys grow up, and you couldn’t then get a cigarette paper between them.It will sadden the Queen that Harry is not there and that he doesn’t seem to get on with his brother any more.As a nation, we have huge rts to heal over Brexit. In her traditional Christmas Day speech the Queen will ask the country to come together and heal the wounds.I’m sure one of her priorities in the New Year will not only be to unite the country, but to bring together her beloved grandsons and their wives.But it’s the Epstein outrage that did most to threaten the House of Windsor this year.The Queen must have been horried to watch the car- crash interview Andrew gave to the BBC.With his arrogance and lack of preparation, Andrew — a Falklands War hero — turned what he hoped could have been his redemption into a nightmare.The Queen, with the advice of the Prince of Wales, acted swtly. Andrew was stripped of his royal duties. The institution has to be protected at all times.Of course, it would have been hard for the Queen to do all this, but she did it with calm and with grace, the hallmarks our redoubtable, -year-old monarch.We should not forget this. This remarkable woman continues to serve us when many would have crumbled.You will not hear the slightest grumble from our Queen.Thank heavens for that.While it seems the royals can do no right, the Queen carries on as normal. She rides her Fell pony most weekends and watches the racing on TV and gets excited when she picks a winner.Her family looks to her at times of ision and uncertainty — and so does the nation.The country is polarised over Brexit and one of the things the Queen wants to see is the isions healed and for people to come together in the New Year.Since he retired, the Duke of Edinburgh has lived in Sandringham, so the Queen is rattling around in her apartments with just servants to talk to. She can’t confide in them like she can the Duke. The scandal that has engulfed Prince Andrew will have saddened her so much. But she won’t abandon her son. She loves him.All families face rts and scandals at one time or another. The Windsors are no dferent. Their story is all about continuity, both for the nation and the Royal Family.So the Queen will have loved the recently released new photographs of herself with the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Cambridge and Prince George preparing a Christmas pudding for charity.It was a royal flush, the Monarch with three generations of heirs. I will be at Sandringham at am tomorrow to photograph theQueen and her family as they arrive at St Mary Magdalene Church.She will pray for the strength to carry on through what are likely to be bumpy roads ahead.And bumps there will be. The Andrew scandal is far from over and  could be a pivotal year for the Duke, who has yet to face the FBI.So when you watch the Queen give her Christmas message tomorrow afternoon, spare a thought for someone who has served this country so dutully and for so long.An amazing woman of true decency and honour.We remain lucky to have her.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rod liddle if i was prime minister
story: And dates. Actually, does anyone still eat dates  Lined up in their narrow little box like cockroaches waiting for the resurrection.Awful bloody things. Yet I still buy a box every Christmas and never eat them.And then tonight. Turkey curry  Turkey salad or turkey sandwiches  Turkey in the basket with sautéed turkey strips in a turkey sauce Why do we do it  Spunk our entire earnings on a day of epic indulgence. I bet the kids are back playing with stuff they DIDN’T get for Christmas by now.And as for the dog . . . well we didn’t want her to feel left out. So we bought her a special Gourmet Dog Christmas Dinner made of . . . yes, turkey. And goose.And our reward for this kindness is to have her lying at our feet all day farting like a wizard.The clouds of gas are so toxic there are flies and spiders dropping dead within ten feet of the animal.Still, it’s what Jesus would have wanted, I suppose.I hope you had a great day and are taking it easy right now. And to those of you working, respect.I quite like working over Christmas Day and Boxing Day. It makes me feel virtuous, which is a rare occurrence.Anyway, there is good reason for cheer this Yuletide. The thick-as-mince rapper Stormzy may have said: “F*** Boris.”But, rather wonderfully, the British people turned out in huge numbers to say, “F*** Stormzy” and: “F*** Magic Grandpa.”It now looks like Brexit will get done and we have a government which MUST respect the wishes of all those new working-class people who voted for it.Boris is doing very well so far. It was a decent Queen’s Speech. And I like the idea his adviser Dominic Cummings has of building new nuclear power plants in the North of England.Lots of well-paid jobs and clean energy. I love nukes, me.But there were a few things missing from Boris’s first programme for government — so I thought I’d help him out.What follows is a list of the stuff I’d like the Government to do.Some of them, as you will see, are very specic to me and might not find accord nationally.It’s a wish list for what I’d do , in some terrible vision of hell, I was ever elected Prime Minister . . . Reduce immigration. I mean really reduce it. To something like nine people per year. I get to choose who the nine are. Most of them will be from Hong Kong. Don’t underestimate the strength of feeling against unlimited immigration, BoJo. Andyou reduce immigration you won’t need to pave over half of our remaining countryside to build new houses. Our urgent need for housing is a consequence of a population expanding because of immigration. Stop sending children to the controversial Tavistock Clinic in London for gender realignment treatment. If people wish to transition, let them wait until they are  . In fact, let’s get rid of all the identity politics stuff. It’s isive and fatuous. We’re all in this together and it doesn’t matterwe’re gay or straight, white or black, Muslim or Christian, Jew or Hindu. Treat everybody equally. And end the hierarchy of whingeing victimhoods. Ban all factory farming. Immediately. Outlaw cats. Scrap the high-speed HS line and spend the money on faster links between the North West of England and the North East. Or spend it all on a TeessideService to replace the crap antiquated trains we have now. Remember how Teesside voted in the election, Boris  Close the polytechnics in which kids who are not very academic pay more than £, to get a worthless degree in gender studies or something. Reduce the number of people going to university by  per cent. Introduce apprenticeships and technical colleges. And scrap tuition fees. Insist that university staff must represent a ersity of opinion. All universities which “no ” speakers to be punished financially. End the BBC licence fee. Insist that cyclists always use cycle lanes where they have been provided. Reduce the number of buses in London by  per cent in off-peak times. Make it illegal for lorries to overtake on two-lane dual carriageways and motorways. Make smoking legal in pubs that I go to. And other pubs,you like. Recognise Jerusalem as being the capital of Israel and move our embassy there. Outlaw the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement for its horrible anti-Semitism. Stop meddling in Middle Eastern politics. Stop invading Muslim countries, or bombing them. Accept that they may not want to live in democracies, or believe what the rest of us believe. Keep a bit of a closer eye on the Chinese state. Increase our military strength to three per cent of GDP. Force Heinz to reintroduce Toast Toppers and Cadbury to reintroduce the Aztec bar. Divert more money from the Premier League to grass-roots football development and also to clubs below the top ision. Especially Millwall, natch. Drop the notion that people who allege that they have been raped MUST be believed. Allow the police to use common sense and discretion. Scrap all elected Police Commissioners and end the politicisation of our police force. Encourage the Old Bill to investigate crimes that genuinely hurt people — like burglaries, assaults and robberies — rather than supposed “hate crimes”. End the badger cull. Now. Make it legal to scratch or deface cars which have a “baby on board” sign in their windows. Recognise that while our country must afford tolerance to all believers in all religions, the United Kingdom is by tradition a Christian country and that Christian values should be especially respected. title: new year resolutions green eco friendly
story: Three-quarters more of us are concerned about the environment than we were in , according to a Sun survey — so many will be considering how to cause less pollution and harmful emissions.Here, I reveal how we can cause less waste, less pollution — and save money at the same time. How low-carbon can you go  Reduce meat and dairy consumption, as beef and sheep livestock have a high carbon footprint. If you’re not ready to go completely without, try Meat Free Mondays Grow your own: You don’t need a big garden. Salad leaves, chilli and herbs are just a few of the things that grow well in containers. It’s a low-cost way of reducing your reliance on super-market fruit and vegetables. Switch off when idle: Leaving TVs, games consoles, the washing machine and microwave on standby eats energy. Some appliances draw energy even when they are not being used and phone chargers are among the worst culprits. “Vampire power” costs each house up to £ a year, according to the Energy Saving Trust. Use energy-saving lightbulbs: LED bulbs can last up to , hours, while some newer models are good for double that. As they use far less energy, you will quickly see impressive savings on your energy bill each month. Which  magazine puts the annual cost of running an LED lightbulb at £., compared to £. for a CFLtype and £. for halogen. Over the course of an LED bulb’s very long letime, it can save you around £. Be a careful cook: Only use as much water as you need and cover your pans so you save energy. Overfilling your kettle is a waste of electricity so only boil as much as you need. Lose the plastic packaging: This wrapping is energy-intensive in its production and causes serious damage to habitats. Choose items that are light on packaging, and refill as much as possible. There is no reason to buy tomatoes on a plastic tray which is also wrapped in plastic. A loose tomato tastes just as good. Find out more about the supermarkets’ war against plastic. Go low: Set the washing machine at C or even C. Doing the laundry at C instead of C can be one third cheaper on energy. For lightly soiled clothes, try C. And make sure that your machine is full. Get free water-saving devices: Moving water around the country and treating it requires huge amounts of energy, so get in touch with your water company to find out what gadgets you can get for free, such as low-flow shower heads which use less water. Make your home cosy: Draught-proof your doors and windows, install secondary-film glazing, top up your loft insulation to cm and get your boiler serviced. Accord-ing to the Energy Saving Trust, loft insulation for a semi-detached house will cost around £, with £ savings a year, while insulating a mid-terrace house will cost around £ and save £ a year. Turn down radiators in rooms you are not using: You don’t need to heat a room you’re not in, so use radiator controls to adjust temperature. Slow down on fast fashion: We buy more and more clothes each year. So choose vintage items, rent something for those special occasions and don’t forget charity shops. Oxfam has a great online shop. For outfit rentals, try websites like byrotation, hirestreetuk and mywardrobehq. If you do really want to buy new clothes, look out for certications of sustain-ability. Use the Good On You app to find out which shops are reducing their impact on the environment. Watch super-market air miles: Potatoes do not rack up air miles like imported rice. Likewise, dairy has a high carbon footprint, so swap a latte for a regular coffee. Look for the Red Tractor symbol on food supplied by British farmers. Buy strawberries, for example, from Norfolk, not Morocco.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The taxi driver brute - whose crimes were retold in ITV’s hit A Confession - killed Becky Godden-Edwards in  and Sian O’Callaghan in . Det Sgt Steve Fulcher was found guilty of gross misconduct for the way he led the investigation.He did not follow procedure when Halliwell confessed and led him to Becky’s body.Now three more officers — two no longer in the police — are being investigated over the “thoroughness” and “adequacy” of the probe.The investigation, conducted by Cambridgeshire Police, is being overseen by the Independent Office for Police Conduct.It was prompted by complaints from a relative of Becky.The three officers have not been named.Halliwell was jailed in  for murdering Sian, , and then again in  for the murder of -year-old Becky, both near Swindon, Wiltshire.MET Police chief Dame Cressida Dick says she will be “extraordinarily co-operative” with watchdogs investigating her handling of a botched VIP paedo ring inquiry.She has been referred to the Independent Office of Police Conduct after the senior officer on Operation Midland called fantasist Carl Beech’s abuse claims “credible and true”.Dame Cressida told the BBC: “I will, of course, be extraordinarily co-operative.“I certainly regret the phrase being used.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: iain duncan smith new year honour theresa may list
story: The Conservative grandee who was narrowly re-elected in the General Election got the gong in their year’s list which was drawn up while former PM Theresa May was in power.That’s despite being a firm Brexiteer who was a thorn in the side of her Premiership.Tory MP Bob Neill has also been made a Knight, and told The Sun his  year-old mother was “absolutely thrilled.”The chairman of the Justice Select Committee in the last Parliament said: “It is an honour, and I’m delighted. I am genuinely really humbled by it.“I’m especially delighted for the family, and especially my mum who is  who brought me up in a semi-detached house in Essex, and supported me in going to university and my career.“She is absolutely thrilled she is an old East End girl who believes in hard work.“I also like to think this is recognition for my work on the Select Committees and for trying to be constructive politically.”Opposition parties said it beggared belief that Sir Iain got the gong for his work creating the controversial Universal Credit system.Liberal Democrat MP Christine Jardine said Sir Iain had been responsible for creating a welfare system in which people were expected to survive for weeks without payment, causing untold stress.It beggars belief that Iain Duncan Smith has been rewarded in the New Years Honours list, she said.He is the architect of Universal Credit - a failed system that has left thousands of families struggling to pay bills and buy food.Labour MP Diana Johnson, who campaigned on behalf of victims of the NHS contaminated blood scandal, is made a dame.The senior Labour MEP Claude Moraes, a long-standing campaigner for refugees and on justice and civil liberties issues, is made an OBE. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new years honour list olivia newton john nadiya hussain
story: The singer, , gets the gong for services to charity, cancer research and entertainment.Olivia, who was born in England but moved to Australia aged five, said: “I am extremely excited, honoured and grateful beyond words to be included with such an esteemed group of women who have received this distinguished award before me.“As a girl born in Cambridge, I am very proud of my British ancestry and so appreciative to be recognised in this way by the United Kingdom.”James Bond director Sam Mendes, , is to be knighted for his contribution to drama.Meanwhile, Sir Elton John, , will have his knighthood upgraded to a Companion of Honour — becoming one of only  living recipients of the award.Steve McQueen, the -year-old Oscar-winning director of  Years a Slave, will also be knighted for services to film.Queen drummer Roger Taylor,  becomes an OBE while singer Billy Ocean, , becomes an MBE for services to music.Snow Patrol’s lead singer Gary Lightbody, , will be made an OBE for services to music and charity. But the news will be bittersweet for him as it comes days after the death of his dad Jack, who had suffered from dementia. His funeral was on Christmas Eve.TV presenter and campaigner June Sarpong, , will be made an OBE, while BBC Sport presenter Gabby Logan, , is to become an MBE.Long-serving Radio  DJ Annie Nightingale, , will be upgraded to a CBE from an MBE.Peaky Blinders creator Steven Knight, , becomes a CBE — and joked that he would be celebrating like Tommy Shelby, the hard-drinking lead character of the hit BBC drama.Playwright James Graham, , whose stage production of the Who Wants to be a Millionaire  cheating scandal was recently adapted for TV, will be made an OBE.And stage star Giles Terera, , best known for playing Aaron Burr in Hamilton, becomes an MBE.There are also awards for several TV cooks. Nigel Slater, , will become an OBE, while Ainsley Harriott, , and Bake Off winner Nadiya Hussain, , are both made MBEs for services to broadcasting and the culinary arts.In total, , people will receive honours, the Cabinet Office said, with . per cent going to women — the second highest for a New Year Honours list, after  per cent in .Schoolboy Ibrahim Yousaf, the youngest on the list at , is to be handed a British Empire Medal for raising thousands of pounds for his community in Oldham.D-Day veteran Harry Billinge, , raised more than £, towards the cost of building a national memorial honouring his fallen comrades and will be made an MBE.Mr Billinge, from St Austell in Cornwall, was just  when he landed on Gold Beach in Normandy on June , .He said: “I did my job and I didn’t want any glory. There’s no glory in war. I’m  and it’s a bit late in le to be recognised.“I am choked beyond measure to think I have got an MBE.“I don’t deserve it. When I get it, it won’t be for me, it will be for the , blokes killed on D-Day.”Battle of Arnhem veteran ­Wilfred Oldham, , from Bury, becomes an MBE for services to commemorations and UK Dutch relations in the Diplomatic Service and Overseas list. Elsewhere, James Booth from Somerset, and Grace Friar, from Northumberland, who were born on the same day  years ago, were recognised for services to their communities and charity.Mete Coban, , from Hackney, East London, is made an MBE for services to young people — after he was moments from being kicked out of the country when border force officials arrived at his home.Mr Coban, originally from northern Cyprus, said: “My parents were served their last notice to be deported back to northern Cyprus, so I think the signicance for them to see their son,  years later, go on and be recognised by the ­honours system, I think it’s huge.Holocaust survivors Mindu Hornick and John Hadju become MBEs for services to Holocaust education and commemoration.Ms Hornick, who lives in Birmingham, said: “I’m  now and it is always an effort to do . But with everything that is going on in the world today, with Islamophobia, anti-Semitism and other unacceptable things that are happening, I think it is important to educate young people.”The Cabinet Office said  per cent of recipients were people who had undertaken outstanding work in their communities, with . per cent of honours going to those from an ethnic-minority background.Organisers said no honours would be considered for those involved in the relief effort of the  Grenfell Tower blaze until the conclusion of the public inquiry — with the ­second phase starting next month.The Sun revealed this week that the heroes who fought off London Bridge attacker Usman Khan in November were due gongs but organisers said they were expected to be considered in future lists.Englands cricket World Cup winners are rewarded for their heroics.All-rounder Ben Stokes is given an OBE, one-day captain Eoin Morgan, gets a CBE while Joe Root and Jos Buttler become MBEs. Coach Trevor Bayliss is made an OBE.Meanwhile, ex-West Indies captain Clive Lloyd, , has his CBE upgraded to a knighthood.England midfielder Jill Scott receives an MBE for services to women’s football and Susan Campbell, director of women’s football at the Football Association, becomes a dame for services to sport.Taekwondo champion Jade Jones, who got an MBE after winning Olympic gold in , has been upgraded to an OBE after her first world title in May.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bride grooms dove release
story: The unknown newly wedded couple chose to gently toss two white doves into the air to mark the special day, but only one took off.It isnt known where or when exactly it took place, but it is thought to have happened in the UK.The clip of the unexpected moment went viral after it was posted on Twitter by Laurie Jane.She wrote: Wait for the magic moment.The bride and groom are filmed stood outside the church after getting married.They are holding a white bird each and both carefully throw their hands up, releasing the doves.The grooms bird flaps off towards the sky, but the brides still dove falls heavily to the ground - as she and the guests look on in horror.After the video was watched more than , times, people commented on it wondering what happened to the bird.One person said the poor birdie, it mustve died in her hands and another added good omen.Earlier this year we told how a bird rescue charity warned against releasing doves at weddings.A spokesperson for Newbury-based bird rescue charity Corvid Dawn wrote on Facebook: Breeders around the country charge a pretty penny to release young birds at weddings.They are often not free flown, meaning they are too exhausted to work out how to get home and havent been in an aviary to to get their bearings or homing instinct, let alone flight muscles.They have no idea how to survive without humans or how to get home.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: civil servants had own way years
story: When something goes so badly wrong, you have to look at what happened and correct it.The Tories changed leaderand have avoided repeating Theresa May’s policy mistakes.They have also worked on their campaign machine, laying the foundations for their recent success. But there is still work to do.Top-down control over who gets a chance to be a candidate is demoralising and messy.And they are still outnumbered by Labour’s membership. It’s time to ride the Boris wave and add , new members to the blue ranks.If Labour keep telling themselves Magic Grandad is perfect, and blaming the voters, then this is a chance for the Conservatives to steal a march.WHILE this dwindling decade was stuffed full of exciting political events, it was not a vintage era for decisive majority ­government.There have been thrills — from voters defying Project Fear to free our country from the EU, through to Boris ­Johnson’s crushing victory over Corbynism.And there have been spills — David Cameron’s abrupt exit from power, Theresa May’s loss of her majority, and the hijack of the Labour Party by the far Left. But there have been only a few moments — mere months in the past ten years — of certain, stable, clear government.We have had two hung parliaments, the uncomfortable alliance of the coalition, and a slim Tory majority which was swtly erted by the EU referendum.At Westminster’s worst, a Remainer Commons — helped by a self-indulgent Speaker — trapped a minority Government in office while denying it the power to do anything.It’s all been very entertaining, but entertainment value is not always a sign of great governmentToo often, hung parliaments and paralysed ministers proved unable to make urgent decisions.Important calls were postponed or fudged out of necessity, because the votes to get on with the job were simply not there.Smashing that obstacle to decision-making is one of the many things about the election result to celebrate.Getting Brexit done should only be the start of the changes made by a Government that at last has the chance to be radical and ambitious.Not everybody will be cheering, however. Obviously, the Opposition aren’t happy. And I expect we will soon see some signs of unhappiness from the upper ranks of the civil service, too.Why  First, because theof majority government is a rude intrusion into the lives of civil service chiefs after a decade in which they got used to getting their own way.The absence of clear authority under May, and before that the many tensions and fractures of the coalition years, offered plenty of opportunity for determined mandarins to manage things just as they liked. No longer.Second, because the days in which the civil service was truly neutral, from top to bottom, have sadly ended — and a troubling number of officials seem to feel it is their role to promote a particular view.Brexit has exposed that bias. In the referendum campaign, public bodies which should know better allowed themselves to be used to pump out Remain propaganda, damaging their reputations.The agenda — to try to delay, disrupt and deny Brexit — was obvious. The election result has at last convinced all but the most diehard EU fans that we really are going to leave.But this is not the only issue on which the Government and parts of officialdom disagree.From Michael Gove’s criticism of experts, to Downing Street’s belief that Whitehall is overdue for radical restructuring and reform, there are changes on the way which will disrupt a state of affairs that rather suited a lot of senior people.If the New Year sees whole departments abolished or merged, and a new culture of ministers challenging the sacred cows of Whitehall thinking, then the machine will fight back, hoping to undermine change and keep things the same. There are three ways for ministers and their advisers to defend against that assault.First, steel themselves for a bumpy ride. They’ll be briefed against by past masters of the targeted Whitehall leak who have little to lose. They must not let themselves be knocked off course.Second, they must find allies. For every hidebound part of the civil service, there are others chafing to see things done better. Bring them on board.Third, they should make full use of their power to make public appointments.Labour stuffed the ious quangos and commissions with like-minded people, with similar principles and priorities.Why wouldn’t they  It would be bizarre for a government to appoint its opponents to wield state power against its agenda.And yet that is exactly what the Tories have too often done, apparently through a misguided sense of fair play.It’s time to realise that the other side neverthe favour. Boris and his team know that the election was the start, not the end, of their job.They have to deliver the change that they promised, to fulfil the trust voters put in them. There are battles ahead to make that happen, and wrestling Whitehall will be one of the biggest. Christmas truce will not last long.THE anti-democratic effort to block Brexit cost time, but it also cost money.Fine, ious big businesses might prefer we had voted Remain.But we didn’t.After the referendum, the private sector stood ready to do what it does best: Adapt and get on with le.But what businesses really dislike is not change so much as uncertainty.And Parliament made uncertainty an art form in the past three years.Now that we’ve got a new deal, a new Commons and a new Government, we should see new investment unlocked.Including money and decisions which were shelved during all the political hurly-burly.Let’s get Brexit done, and get Britain booming.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queens brooch during christmas shows shes a remainer
story: The monarch’s sapphire and diamond jewellery, matching a royal blue cashmere dress, allegedly showed her support for the European Union.Dr James Anderson said the outfit’s colour-scheme’s similarity to the EU flag shows the Queen’s allegiance to Brussels.The Reading University academic tweeted: “The Queen has full editorial control of the Queen’s Speech and can choose whether or not to give one. She chose not to in .So treat the speech as her personal views, right down to her choice of an EU blue dress and an EU stars brooch.Dr. Geoff Jones, an aeronautical engineer, added: “Her Majesty yet again doing what little she can to show her support for the European Union.”While other Remainers on Twitter pointed out that the Queen wore the brooch when addressing the EU in .However, not everyone was convinced the -year-old monarch was sending out a statement on Brexit.One tweeter wrote: “More likely the blue was chosen to stand out against the background that sapphire brooch was a gt from Albert to Victoria.“Taken as a whole with the photos of her father, husband and next three heirs, I think she is emphasising family and continuity.”Another said: Pretty desperate stuff. Focus on the message and not the attire. And in that spirit........Merry Christmas.One man added: Any more straws to clutch at While Sky’s royal commentator Alastair Bruce said: “The Queen wears the sapphire broach that the last Queen Regnant, Queen Victoria was given as a wedding present by her husband, Prince Albert of Saxe Coburg Gotha, in .”During the speech the Queen described her family’s year as “bumpy” but described the birth of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle’s baby Archie as a “delight”.Her Majesty, posing in front of family snaps, said: “The path, of course, is not always smooth, and may at times this year have felt quite bumpy, but small steps can make a world of dference.”

title: brussels wants its own brexit extension
story: The Withdrawal Agreement struck with the EU allows the so-called implementation period to be extended by up to two years.During that period EU rules will still apply here but the UK will have no role in making decisions.But a fortnight ago the PM vowed to make any extension illegal - meaning Britain will be free of the orbit of EU rules by December .Today European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen set Brussels for an immediate collision course with the UK in the New Year.She told a French newspaper that both sides would have to re-evaluate how trade negotiations are going in the middle of , before deciding whether to extend the transition period beyond December .Speaking to French daily les Echos, the EU chief said: “It would be reasonable to evaluate the situation mid-year and then,necessary, agree on extending the transition period.Her comments cast fresh doubt on whether a new UK-EU trade deal can be ready in time for when the transition period ends next year.UK EU trade would revert to basic World Trade Organisation rules - hiking tarfs and customs red tape -no new trade agreement is in place.Mr Johnsons move to set a hard deadline to talks is designed to call the EU’s bluff ahead of the start of negotiations over Britain’s future trading relationship with Brussels.It means Britain could not prolong trade negotiations evenit wanted to and stops Brussels winding down the clock on trade negotiations to force Britain into accepting an extension.A Government spokesman said: “The Prime Minister has been clear that we will not be extending the Implementation Period.“Both the EU and the UK committed to agreeing a future partnership by the end of  in the Political Declaration and have agreed to work with great energy to achieve this.”
