title: tranent-youngster-selling-reindeer-food-good-cause
story: Archie Lusk, eight, of Meetinghouse Drive, decided he wanted to raise money to help the homeless this Christmas, so opted to make reindeer food to sell rather than spend money on Christmas cards.The reindeer food, made by the P Ormiston Primary School pupil, is a mix of oats and other special ingredients.It is packaged with a label that reads: ldquoSprinkle on the lawn at night, the moon will make it sparkle bright, as Santarsquos reindeers fly and roam, this will guide them to your home.Archie has already raised pound. The reindeer food is on sale for pound a bag anyone who wants to buy some can pop into Hoi Barbers in Tranent or message his mum Victoria Johnston on Facebook.

title: volunteers-offering-free-christmas-dinner-christmas
story: This is the third year the event has been held at the church, on New Street, on December .Sarah Shearer, whose husband Graham is pastor, said Wednesdayrsquos three-course dinner, including turkey and all the trimmings, had places for  people in total.The invitation is extended to those who will be on their own during the festive season, residents in financial crisis, the bereaved or families which have split up and cannot afford a Christmas meal.Mrs Shearer said: ldquoWe hope the number of people wishing to attend will keep rising and we can provide transportneeded. We had  people last year and would love to increase that this year.ldquoWe have single parent families joining us for the first time this year. It is all about people just wanting to feel part of the community. There is no criteria for attending, we have an open door policy.She added: ldquoIt is to ease the burden and for people to feel the Christmas spirit and be looked after, and go home and enjoy Christmas with their own families.A team of  volunteers will support the event, which is funded by donations. In the kitchen will be Mrs Shearer and Naomi Matthews, who has also made up gt bags for guests.Mr and Mrs Shearerrsquos own five children are looking forward to the event, held from noon to .pm.A Basics Bank is held at the church each Thursday, am-noon, offering food donations to people who are officially referred, but lsquoblessings bagsrsquo containing food are also given out to those in need.

title: major-junction-work-start-a1-near-queen-margaret-university
story: The work, due to start in April next year, has generally been welcomed but there are fears that traffic from the development will clog up Musselburghrsquos road network.The QMU A junction improvements, approved by East Lothian Council planners under delegated powers, follow two planning applications from Persimmon Homes for more than  hectares of land surrounding the university, at Craighall, already getting the go-ahead.Detailed planning permission for  new homes was approved for part of the site north of the A at Monktonhall.It is anticipated that the majority of the remaining , homes will be built south of the A.There are also plans to build a new primary school south of the A for the future Craighall community, where there will also be three full-size sports pitches and new lsquocycle superhighwaysrsquo created using a railway line which runs under the dual carriageway.The masterplan for the land, which stretches from Stoneybank and Newcraighall in the north down past the village of Old Craighall, shows about  hectares of the land south of the A set aside for housing and the school, with a further  hectares for employment.North of the A, more than  hectares have been earmarked for housing and an innovation park supporting research work at the university.Land has also been set aside for the possible expansion of Musselburgh Railway Station in future.A planning report stated that junction completion works, put forward by East Lothian Council, would involve the construction of new slip-roads to the A northbound carriageway which would meet in a roundabout, providing arms to the development areas and a link road to the existing junction at QMU.The existing junction A southbound slip-roads would be retained and enhanced with extended auxiliary lanes to ease traffic movement. The existing junction in front of QMU would also be modied from a give-way ghost island T-junction to a signalised junction with greater capacity to hold turning traffic.The proposed scheme would, through the provision of an underpass beneath the A and slip roads to the northbound carriageway of the A, enable traffic movement from QMU and the new development to access the A northbound directly.Street lighting is proposed to be installed extended to include the new section of Queen Margaret Drive which would be provided under the A to the proposed roundabout junction. Street lighting would also be provided on the new slip roads.The proposals also include foot and cycle paths, two SUDS ponds, mitigation planting of native woodland to the main junction, structure tree planting, marginal planting to the proposed SUDS areas, and more ornamental planting to the areas near the QMU campus.Colin Beattie, Musselburgh MSP, said: ldquoWhile I welcome improvements to the road system which will accommodate the exciting new business developments around QMU, I am less enthusiastic about the huge expansion of housing, albeit much-needed, adjacent to QMU.ldquoThey will substantially increase the traffic on that stretch of road. Hopefully the improvements will manage that well.ldquoI continue to have concerns about developments being put in place with inadequate attention to overall infrastructure needs and the impact on surrounding residents.Barry Turner, spokesman for Musselburgh Conservation Society, added: ldquoThough we do not want this amount of housing in this location, we hope that the improved junction will channel much of the traffic generated onto the A and away from Musselburgh.ldquoThere are already serious traffic problems at the bottom end of Monktonhall Road and at the Tesco roundabout. Evenjust some of the traffic from the development around QMU comes this way to access facilities in Musselburgh, we fear the road system will clog up totally.ldquoWe have no problem with the junction improvements. Our issue is with the amount of housing proposed, which is totally inappropriate.Councillor John Williamson added: ldquoThe planned developments will technically be part of Musselburgh, although the vast majority of the new housing will be on the western side of the A with the only direct access to Musselburgh itself, as far as Irsquom aware, restricted to public transport and cycle pedestrian access.ldquoThe only full vehicle access will be via Newcraighall or Old Craighall Roundabout, which means that it will be dficult for the new communities to feel an integral part of Musselburgh.A spokesperson for QMU said: ldquoWe welcome news of the approval of planning permission for the A QMU road junction which will help unlock the full potential of the site for the development of the Innovation Park.ldquoQMU chose to move to East Lothian partly because of the opportunities to work with employers to develop the land immediately adjacent to the new campus.ldquoThe decision is the latest in a series of important milestones that have brought us a step closer to progressing plans for sustainable economic development.

title: family-bonnie-babies-champion-2019-celebrate-victory
story: This yearrsquos winner is Rhea McKinlay, who was born on April  in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh at .am.Her mum Rebecca Mackenzie, , from Whiteloch Road in Macmerry, told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom very surprised, I really wasnrsquot expecting [Rhea] to win the top prize but Irsquom really happy.Rhearsquos dad Fraser McKinlay, , who works at the University of Edinburgh, is also happy with the result.Rebecca said: ldquoHe wasnrsquot as into it as me and wasnrsquot that fussed but is very happy she has won.ldquoHe did help me write some of the coupons, though.Before going on maternity leave, Rebecca worked as a nurse in the Royal Infirmary but will soon start a new job as a community nurse in Midlothian.Her secret to achieving so many votes was her mum Nicola Mackenzie.Rebecca, who has lived in Macmerry all her le, said: ldquoMy mum works in the local shop so she had been asking the local people and her customers to vote for Rhea.ldquoBecause she works there, everyone knows her and everyone knows Rhea.Rhea has recently learned to crawl, with Rebecca saying the year had ldquoflown by.Rhea is described by Rebecca as a ldquoreally good, happy wee baby who is ldquoalways smiling.Her favourite teddy is a purple bunny that is always with her wherever she goes.She also loves swimming and regularly attends a turtle tots class in Haddington.On what they are going to do with their pound prize, Rebecca admitted she would probably put most of it into savings for Rhearsquos future ndash but may also purchase some more swimming class sessions for their little bundle of joy.The amount she does not save will be spent on another lot of swimming classes since they are one of Rhearsquos favourite things to do and Rebecca doesnrsquot want them to stop.

title: bid-test-rocket-engines-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-rejected
story: Skyrorarsquos bid to set up a base on where the sitersquos former coal handling plant stood had caused a ision between neighbouring community councils and saw nearly  objections lodged with East Lothian Council.And at a meeting of the local authorityrsquos planning committee last Wednesday, the proposal was rejected against the advice of council officials after planning convenor Councillor Norman Hampshire branded the development a ldquobad neighbour.Mr Hampshire told fellow committee members that he was concerned that allowing Skyrora to test rocket engines on the land, which is central to the councilrsquos future economic plans, could put other investors off.He said: ldquoThis is not a good neighbour ndash it is a bad neighbour development and my concern is this may deter potential investors from taking on development at the Cockenzie site.Skyrora had lodged an application to create a rocket engine testing site on the land, which is owned by the local authority, with plans to carry out five -second tests each month.But while it applied for temporary use of the site for five years, Skyrora told the planning committee that it envisaged the possibility of not just expanding its presence in the community but potentially bringing a manufacturing facility, described as the size of an Ikea store, to the area.And while Prestonpans Community Council supported the move as offering potential for jobs and the economy, neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council objected.At the planning committee meeting last week, Bryan Hickman, chairman of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, recalled a public meeting in the summer which attracted several hundred people.He said: ldquoVirtually everyone who was there was against it ndash ranging from our youngest residents to pensioners.ldquoThe feeling, rightly or wrongly, in the community is that they do not want it.During the council meeting, residents raised concerns about the storage of key elements of fuel on the site for days prior to testing, as well as the impact of burning kerosene into the atmosphere.While Skyrora insisted that the engine tests would be a ldquoclean burn producing mainly water, resident and biochemist Dr Brian Hall told the committee that he estimated about , litres of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide could be released during each -second test.Calum Miller, on behalf of Prestonpans Community Council, urged councillors to approve the plans, pointing out that the power station site had lain empty now for six years.He told them: ldquoThe council has the opportunity with this Skyrora application to dispel the myth that we are too remote from Edinburgh to attract business.Ward councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell, Lachlan Bruce and Neil Gilbert did not support the application.Ms OrsquoDonnell said that the impact on local amenity would be unacceptable and spoke of the ldquohigh level of public concern from constituents about the proximity of the test site to housing ndash the nearest of which was estimated at  metres away.Councillors rejected the planning application by six votes to two.The decision was welcomed by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council chairman Mr Hickman, who said: ldquoThe community is very pleased about the decision as expressed on social media and meeting residents as I go about.ldquoI felt that we presented a strong case against the application.ldquoThe councillors present gave a fair and balanced summary before coming to their decision. The community thanks the ward councillors who called in the application.ldquoIf this did not go before the committee, it would have been approved by East Lothian Council planning department.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, said that he hoped the council would now turn attention to calls for a cruise port at the former power station site, which has been supported by his members. He said: ldquoI am disappointed that local ward councillors went against the advice of their council officers on this planning application.ldquoHopefully this will focus East Lothian Council councillors and officials on pushing forward the cruise port initiative to secure much-needed jobs in East Lothian.And his community council colleague Mr Miller criticised councillors for failing to listen to their officials.He said: ldquoIt was patently obvious that councillors on the planning committee couldnrsquot get their heads around the nuances of decibels and emissions.ldquoThey should have fallen back on advice from their own experienced officials. Instead, they repeated the junk science coming from cranks in Cockenzie.ldquoEach test would have generated the same emissions as a family car running for a year. The councillors who referenced a climate emergency in defence of their decision were only too happy to drive home from Haddington.ldquoAn ecosystem of space technology companies could have emerged in East Lothian based around the testbed.ldquoThe wilful ignorance of a few has pulled opportunity for the hands of young people in East Lothian.Derek Harris, from Skyrora, said he was disappointed by the decision of the planning committee.It is understood the company will take time to consider whether to appeal the decision.Mr Harris said: ldquoI would like to thank all the staff at East Lothian Council who helped with our application. I am disappointed by the decision but it went through the democratic process.

title: mekala-osbornes-family-put-christmas-hold-recovers
story: The -year-old, from Wallyford, a former Preston Lodge High School pupil, fell ill while travelling through Vietnam with what was originally diagnosed as bronchial pneumonia.After being put into an induced coma in a critical condition, Mekala was moved to a hospital in Singapore before she eventually travelled to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.Mekalarsquos mum Yvonne Bonnar McAulay said Mekala was now able to sit up in a chair for several hours a day and was being weaned off a ventilator however she said it feels like a bit of a ldquostandstill time in her recovery.She told the Courier: ldquoDue to everything thatrsquos happened, we feel itrsquos appropriate to put Christmas on hold.ldquoWe will have a wee breakfast for [her brother] Danny: he doesnrsquot understand Christmas so itrsquos pretty much another day for him, but we are doing our best to give Danny his own wee special Christmas Day.ldquoGranny is helping out so I can spend the afternoon and some of the night with Mekala.ldquoIt is a long road ahead as she needs to get her lungs working properly and then concentrate on gaining her muscle back throughout her body, then physio will start.ldquoShe will be in isolation until after the year. All being well we can start rehab, physio etc and that will be when the real hard work starts.ldquoHow strong she is will determine when she leaves hospital.ldquoFortunately, shersquos a very fit young lady which has gotten her this far. The best Christmas gt we got was having her back in Scotland. And shersquos still smiling.An online fundraising page set up to support her family while they stayed by her side in Asia raised more than pound,.

title: mum-gives-fresh-meal-kits-need-christmas
story: Jane Russell, , of Harlawhill Gardens, has been flooded with donations as well as appeals for help from families in the county since she posted on Facebook that she was willing to drop off the fresh meal kits.The mum-of-three was inspired to help those in need because only a few years ago she was struggling herself, and whilst she thinks foodbanks are great, she knows that some people can be hesitant to use them.She wanted to offer a mobile alternative for families, providing them with fresh food.Janersquos family have all got involved and have set up the Facebook page lsquoSunday fresh chicken dinner boxesrsquo so families can get in touch.Their meal kit includes: a fresh whole chicken, fresh herbs, potatoes, broccoli, carrots, onions, Yorkshire puddings, gravy granules and selection boxes or biscuits.Jane said: ldquoI never imagined that it would grow this big but since I posted on Facebook it has just snowballed.ldquoI wouldnrsquot be able to do all of this myself and so many people have offered to help out, which is amazing.ldquoWe now have four drivers helping and I keep coming home to bags of food and chickens on my doorstep.ldquoThe idea was originally that I would deliver them on a Friday so that the families would have everything necessary for Sunday dinner but wersquore now delivering Wednesday to Sunday.ldquoAnd we were only going to do this up until Christmas but we are going to extend it until after New Year because we know the foodbank closes for a period and wersquod like to help anyone struggling over that time.ldquoMy kids have been helping make the boxes up at night and my youngest two even dress up as elves to help.Jane who has two children at Preston Tower Primary School, Prestonpans, and one at Musselburgh Grammar School, has been inundated with requests from families in the county and where she even had a message from someone in the USA on social media who did not realise she was based in East Lothian.She is only able to deliver within the county and has been ldquoheartbroken to have to say no to some families but her act of kindness has inspired others to pick up the task of producing boxes for other areas.Jane is also fundraising to start up her Prestonpans-based charity The Young Minds Hub to help young people with mental health issues.To request a box, contact the Facebook page lsquoSunday fresh chicken dinner boxesrsquo.

title: busy-boxing-day-emergency-services-east-lothian
story: Coastguard, RNLI, police and paramedics were called out to three separate emergencies across the county.At about .pm, North Berwickrsquos RNLI and coastguard volunteers were alerted to kayakers in dficulty at Canty Bay, to the east of the town.One had capsized and was struggling to get back into the kayak in the cold sea.The kayakers, who were correctly kitted out, put in a Mayday call to the coastguard, who requested the launch of the leboat.A spokesman for North Berwick RNLI said: ldquoOur volunteers left their ious Boxing Day lunches and family activities and quickly launched the leboat, only to be stood down shortly after launching.ldquoThe kayakers had managed to self-rescue and made it safely back to North Berwick.ldquoCalling for assistance early is always the best option as it allows rescue assets to be stood up and start making their way to assist, eventhey are stood down afterwards.The kayakers were met at the townrsquos harbour and found to be safe and well.Shortly after pm, the two volunteer teams received a second call.Joined by colleagues from the police and Scottish Ambulance Service, they attended at Seaclf after reports of a woman falling and injuring herself while out walking with her family.The woman suffered minor facial injuries and was put on a stretcher before being carried to a waiting ambulance.Finally, the coastguard team received a call at about pm following reports that a person had fallen into the harbour at Port Seton.Coastguard colleagues from Fisherrow also attended, alongside police and paramedics.The person received treatment from the paramedics.

title: six-east-lothian-residents-new-year-honours-list
story: Included on the list is county golf legend Catriona Matthew, who receives an OBE for services to the sport.Earlier this year, Matthew, from North Berwick,captained Europe to victory over the USA at the Solheim Cup at Gleneagles.Meanwhile, Professor JohnPickard, from Gullane, receives a CBE for services to neurosciences, neurosurgery and research for patients with complex neurological disorders.Colin Taylor of Musselburgh, former headteacher at Newbattle Community High School in Midlothian, receives an MBE for services to education and to the community in Midlothian and East Lothian.Arthur Dyke, from Musselburgh, will receivea British Empire Medal for services to Poppyscotland.Heserved with the Scots Guards for  years and toured Germany, Hong Kong and Ireland.The former Lance Sergeant began working at the Lady Haig Poppy Factoryin Edinburgh in and retired earlier this year due to ill health after  years.Jean Alexander Watt Thomson receives a BEM for services to the community in Prestonpans.Jean was a member of the original steering group for the Harlawhill Day Care Centre and has remained on the board of trustees, chairing it for the last two years.And Andrew Hogarth, formerly area amenity officer at East Lothian Council, receives a BEM for services to parks and bioersity in East Lothian.Andrew, from Tranent,has worked for East Lothian Council and its predecessorEast Lothian District Council for his entire career ndash  years.

title: top-100-tunes-scotland-2019-part-1-100-76
story: Shock of the year goes to Lewis Capaldi, that guy from Bathgate with the silly YouTube videos whose songs of break-up and lack of self worth captivated not this country, not just the UK, but the world. There did not seem to be a country where Somebody You Loved was not number one.It was that everyman persona that has catapulted Castlemilk lad Gerry Cinnamon into our consciousness, and he showed this year that there was more to THAT party hit Belter.There were surprises when the Afro-futurist Radio Highleby Glasgow DJ and producer Auntie Flo, also known as Brian dSouza, won this years prestigious Scottish Album of the Year Award.It was certainly a "huge surprise" to him, as was playing a live set at Skye Live Festival and dishing champagne out to the crowd as he was announced winner.Here is my annual playlist of what I considered to be the essential tunes to come out of Scotland.This best of Scottish soundtrack for  is an erse journey into hip hop, alternative, dance, house, electronica, indie, punk, post-grunge, post-rock, nu and old folk, even hints of classical and often a combination of some or all.Its a mix of the known, little known and the unknown, leftfield and mainstream, immediate pop anthems and challenging experimental projects.This list has been whittled down from a not very shortlist of nearly  compiled throughout the year.And we start with...Part  - - .... with Parts ,  and , tomorrow, Saturday and SundayThe Kidney Flowers - ClosedThe Animal Mothers, stalwarts on the underground Glasgow psyche live scene recommended this crazed trio and their debut album full of buzzsaw guitar anthems does all the things I would want from rock, manic pop thrills, screaming rfs, and screaming blue murder. Sensational. Faex Optim - Wilderness PatternTheres no doubting post-electro masters Boards of Canada are the inspiration for this swirling downtempo soundscape from the Edinburgh producer aka Wesley Macdonald. It features on the soundtrack to Adventures in Nature a short film by Chris Cox.StIndigo - GhostUp and coming Edinburgh-based rapper aka Bailey Ellis aimed high with his Garage Band-produced mix tape Azulkaya and hits the spot with this R Rated beaut.EMarvellous - Never The Mental HealthScotland-based rapper with a smooth flow and an infectiously funky backing track bringing mental health awareness Gallus - Actual FactualRiotous Glasgow combo with a ripsnorting guitar rf meltdown and a saxophoneoverlaying a run about the InfoWars. Catholic Action- One of UsThe SAY Award-nominated Glasgow quartet Catholic Actions lead single from forthcoming album Celebrated by Strangers is a fuzzed-out glam racket of a tune.Lead singer and guitarist Chris McCrory says: "One of Us was written as a direct response to what I see happening in the UK ndash a country ravaged by poverty and a disintegrating social fabric of increasingly isolated and intoxicated people. A neglected group spun in circles by an uncaring billionaire-owned media, led into pointing the finger at one another as opposed to those truly responsible for this situation.Pictish Trail - Turning BackIsle of Eiggs Pictish Trails synth-heavy corker Turning Back is fromincoming album Thumb World due out on February . Star Rover - Here We Go AgainThree-piece Edinburgh guitar-pop combos earwormthird single taken from their second album Minor Miracles which was recorded and produced atChamber Studio in the capital. Youth Team - Routines#Standout from Survival, Evasion, Resistance, Escape, thethird album from -year-old ambient electro whizz Angus Upton from Braemar who describes it as asoundtrack to a movie thatit did exist "would have been directed by John Carpenter, starred Kurt Russell, made between  and  and well, you can figure the plot out".Survival, Evasion, Resistance, Escape by Youth Team Siobhan Wilson - AprilThe Scots singer-songwriter is at her best on this message of empowerment from latest album The Departure."Its a song Ive written for my teenage self, she says, a call to ldquosmash up the ideal way of existing, and promote the idea to create your own existence. The Wild Places - Crime of the CenturyFirst single from the forthcoming debut album by the Radiohead-nodding Glasgow trio is a four minute surf rockin aural journey through a forgotten Tarantino movie.Crime of the century by The Wild Places Calvin Harris ft Rag n Bone Man - Giant#This infectious earworm from the Dumfries superstar DJ-producer was all over pop radio and peaked at number two on the UK Singles Chart for five consecutive weeks. It was kept from the top by Scot Lewis Capaldis Someone You Loved which maintained its peak for seven consecutive weeks.Flynns Ego - Grand Edgelord Overture [Pubertus Noctum]From a debut album It Hates You! .#.#.#but not quite as much as it hates itself comes this experimentally hilarious sample-heavy style convulsion of metal, electronica, and what sounds like a Greek bouzouki, out of Edinburgh topped off with burps and comedian Stewart Lee. You wont have heard anything like it.Damn Dirty Duke - Total Organisation#What started off two years ago as an art installation created by Colette Dryburgh and Detroit Law using synths and props against a backdrop of self-shot film footage turned into a gothic electronic monster. This warped art-punk highlight from their debut Multi Muscle Disciplinary is an ugly beautul part sneered, part sung peach.Top  Tunes from Scotland in  Part  TNGHT - Club Finger#An absurdist rave culture aping jam with a bass to blowbrain cells and one of the many highlights on the freaky new EP from the collaboration between Glasgowrsquos Hudson Mohawke and Montrealrsquos Lunice.Sinister South- FTW#A brutal no-holds-barred R Rated no future view of the world from the fiercesome hip hop Glasgow foursome. title: top-100-tunes-scotland-2019-part-2-75-51
story: This best of Scottish soundtrack for  is an erse journey into hip hop, alternative, dance, house, electronica, indie, punk, post-grunge, post-rock, nu and old folk, even hints of classical and often a combination of some or all.Its a mix of the known, little known and the unknown, leftfield and mainstream, immediate pop anthems and challenging experimental projects.This list has been whittled down from a not very shortlist of nearly  compiled throughout the year.Top  Tunes from Scotland in  Part  Part - - The Reverse Engineer - Hexadecagonal Septagram#Championed on this list last year, Dave House released his latest EP through Edinburgh-based Paradise Palm Records. This standout track from his Euclidean Acid EP stays closest to his most experimental off-kilter side, while embracing a more acid and trance-influenced dancefloor orientated sound, albeit the weirdest seven minutes you will ever hear at a club. SOPHIE ft Kim Petras - Reason Why#The Scots bred producerfirst premiered this hyperkinetic electro-pop nugget at a festival in May , after premiering another collaboration with Kim Petras,,, Dayz Up. This is one of the best.ldquoWhen we initially approached Ben to work with us on Violence we gave him free reign to do whatever he wanted," saysfrontman Tom Smith. "It seemed stupid to try and instill any boundaries or direction to him as he has such a singular, authored sound to everything he puts his hand tohellip so we left him to it. The results of that process being this release. A very visceral version of our album Violence.Sacred Paws - Brush Your HairFormerScottish Album of the Year winning Glasgow-London afro-surf duomade a comeback with a new album and this exuberanttaster. Be Charlotte - Do Not DisturbOvera year after inking a deal with Sony Columbia, Dundee-bornCharlotte Brimner swith a ridiculously catchy slice of popwhose premise finds the singer after an argument with persons unknown unable to talk to them. Bis - Sound of a HeartbreakThe Glasgow trio who are celebrating their th anniversary began their new album Slight Disconnects with a spiky bubblegum punk pop bang.Top  Tunes from Scotland in  Part   The Kidney Flowers- Every Time You Come#The little known three-piece Glasgow primitive DIY garage rockers have not just created one of the most exciting rock albums of the year in Scotland they are broke. As of December , they posted: "Were still in debt over the physical release, so prove youre not a Tory and buy a record." title: How Britain  woke  up in 2019     and what we saw wasn t nice
story: ldquoWoke only entered the Oxford English Dictionary last year as meaning ldquoalert to racial or social discrimination and injustice. Like its parent ldquopolitically correct, woke is a passion of the urban left. It is PC for the age of LGBTQIA+. suggested ldquowoke as word of the year, which arguably it should be, though not for the reason it thinks. For woke has changed meaning in the last  months, and become a term of derision, referring to a style of self-righteous, right-on thinking favoured by, well,columnists. It is now used to denote the metropolitan identity politics that contributed to Labourrsquos greatest defeat since the s.:Guy Stenhouse: Time to Get Over itNo-one is sure where the word ldquowoke came from, except that it emerged from African-American vernacular for ldquostaying alert, as in ldquostay woke, brother. In recent years it was adopted by the BlackLivesMatter movement with their hashtag #staywoke ndash meaning keeping black issues uppermost on social media.It was soon adopted by white millennials to emblemise not just racial awareness but a whole identitarian outlook on le. Woke expresses the ultra-feminist, multi-ethnic, gender non-conforming culture fashionable in American and UK campuses.Woke people love people of colour and loathe ldquostraight white males, ldquogammon and ldquoboomers. They adore so-called ldquonon-binary people who claim not to identy with any gender. No-one is quite sure what non-binary means. Do they swing both ways  No, thatrsquos bisexual. Are they transgender  Definitely not, and nor are they intersex. Itrsquos one of lersquos mysteries to many folk who are less woke.Wokeness has recently taken the media and advertising world by storm. Companies eager to keep up with the zeitgeist waste no chance to wave the rainbow flag and include multi-ethnic themes. This is sometimes called ldquowoke-washing. Every TV advert from McDonaldrsquos to John Lewis now has to feature a multi-racial family, asthe advertisers believe having two white people on one sofa is racism.The BBC drama Years And Years was kind of Woke Family Robinson. Black professhysional mother, transshygender daughter, gay cousin, asylum-seeker boyfriend, disabled sister ... all fighting the good fight against the emerging fascism of Brexit Britain. This compendium of woke identitarianism came complete with a middle-aged white dad. He naturally emerged as a morally worthless, adulterous creep, fit only to be punished by losing all his money.: Mark Smith: Happy Christmas First Minister ndash here are some questions I think you should answerWoke is easy to satirise and has been, mercilessly, by the comedian Andrew Doyle with his social media creation, Titania McGrath. She is a -year-old middle-class gender studies graduate, obsessed by her imagined victimhood, who identies as an ecosexual, non-binary person of colour and fights for social justice by writing bad poetry. ldquoThe only thing thatrsquos white about me, says Titania, ldquois my skin.She firmly believes women can have penises and that people should have electronic chips inserted in their brains to report heterosexual thinking. Men who have sexual dreams are guilty of rape, according to Titania.Woke folk thought Titania was the product of the homophobic, alt-right, fascist MSMndash or did until her creator, a gay Labour voter, was exposed last year. She is one of the great satirical creations of the century, just donrsquot expect Doyle to get invited on to The Mash Report.Woke is no joke. The leftrsquos penchant for strict identity politics, and the exotic fringes of LGBTQIA+ has had political consequences. The social media assault on ldquowhite working-class Brexit voters as racists and bigots was a factor in the alienation of traditional Labour constituencies. People in Bolsover, Workington and Sedgefield donrsquot much like being portrayed as fascists. Who knew There is a sanctimoniousness and intolerance about woke culture that is itself sometimes redolent of the authoritarian right, especially its approach to language. Anyone who mistakenly says ldquocoloured people instead of ldquopeople of colour, for example, will be ostracised. Pronouns must be obeyed. Feminist academics are no-edthey question whether transwomen are biologically female.Barack Obama warned the Democratic Party to avoid this ldquowoke politics with its ldquocancel culture. This is the practice of social justice warriors on Twitter demonising anyone who fails to conform to their particular form of non-conformism. If Trump wins again, it will in part because the Democrats havenrsquot listened.There is an anti-science, quasi-religious aspect to woke. Woke biology insists that sex is not innate but is ldquoattributed at birth ndash asevery child is born transgender. During the General Election campaign, the Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson tried, with disastrous results, to defend the woke dogma that biological sex doesnrsquot exist.Woke wars are raging in the Scottish National Party and have been since Nicola Sturgeon declared her support for self-ID ndash a law change to allow transgender people to self-identy as women without the need for medical intervention or convincing evidence that they have lived as women.There has been a vigorous reaction against this from feminists in and out of the SNP. They fear womenrsquos refuges, changing rooms and prisons are liable to be invaded by men declaring themselves to be female. They also resent being called ldquocis by wokeasians, aswomen are merely a subset of their own sex.The General Election has not caused any obvious soul-searching among the woke cadres. Indeed, the verdict ofwriter Paul Mason was a pitch-perfect expression of the woke worldview. The election was, he declared, ldquoa victory of the old over the young racists over people of colour selfishness over the planet.Such is the firm belief of the morally superior who spend their lives in an echo chamber saving the world from imagined hate crimes. It will take more than a landslide defeat to persuade them otherwise.

title: issue-day-steamie
story: The Steamie The comedy-drama is set in a Glasgow wash-house and follows the lives of a group of women as they try to get their laundry completed in the run up to the Hogmanay bells in , with their chatter at the heart of the play.A wash-house For the uninitiated, the "steamie" was a communal facility where the clothes were cleaned in the pre-washing machine era and on Hogmanay, it was a tradition for everything to be cleaned for the New Year ndashthe house, clothes, curtainshellipIf you are the "talk of the steamie" The saying lives on, meaning you are the subject of hot gossip, just as you would have been discussed by the women as they did their laundry back in the day.The play is one of Scotlandrsquos biggest theatre success stories It is now, but was initially rejected repeatedly by theatres and TV production firms. Then in stepped the Wildcat Theatre Company, which had been offered an out-of-the-blue grant for a play specically about a community and had no time to commission one. It took a chance on The Steamie, that had been criticised for having no plot as such, rather focusing on the womenrsquos conversation as a narrative.Tony Roperrsquos the writer Now , Glasgow-born Roper is the writer and director. His first major starring role was in the sketch show, Scotch and Wry, starring Rikki Fulton.It was memorably filmed for STV First staged at Jordanhill College in Glasgow in , an enduring version was made by STV for Hogmanay , starring Dorothy Paul, Katy Murphy, Eileen McCallum and Peter Mullan.The Steamie was revolutionary Mr Roper said it broke new ground ldquobecause it was written by an actor", adding: ldquoThat doesnt fit into the plan that actors act, writers write and directors direct. It also featured a lot of women which was unusual. Most plays were all men with a token woman. This was all women with a token man. At the time, all of the plays about women were feminist plays. They had a point to prove. Although lsquoThe Steamiersquo didnt preach a message, it was revolutionary for its day.Itrsquos back in Glasgow It takes to the stage of the SSE Hydro tonight, with the last performance of the run on Hogmanay.Roper is glad to see his workto the city He said: ldquoIn my late s I sat down with a Biro and a jotter and wrote my first ever play. Over three decades later, the play is still getting the laughs and the cries, connecting with another generation of Scots."I cannot wait to bring the show ndash with more music and a spectacular cast ndash to the countryrsquos biggest entertainment venue.MAUREEN SUGDEN

title: letters-first-minister-deliberately-avoiding-key-questions
story: The First Minister, and I suspect most of the rest of Scotland, know the honest answers to the questions Mr Smith has posed, but equally she is aware that they are inconvenient to her cause.A referendum in  is not a genuine ambition of the First Minister, partly because polls suggest the result might not be in her favour, but also because, as experts have stated, logistically there would not be enough time to hold it next year. Instead the earliest it could happen would be one to two years after the  Holyrood elections.On the mandate issue, while Nicola Sturgeon claims it is ldquounarguable, she is well aware of many potential arguments against it, not least because the latest General Election was primarily about Brexit. Equally, for many in Scotland the expectation that the result of the  referendum should stand for a reasonable period,not a generation, should not be overturned by a change in circumstancesopinion polling suggests those changes have not signicantly shted support for independence.As for whether leaving the UK would be more complex and painful than leaving the EU, no one observing the machinations of the last three years of negotiations can think it would be anything but far worse to disentangle from the much closer and deeply seated UK union.Finally, the First Minister will not want to publicly contemplate what she would dothe majority for independence in any future referendum was only slight. Would less than one per cent still be enough  Would a statistical draw be taken as justying separation  Mr Sturgeonrsquos sense of fairness would have her answer no to that, but the ingrained nationalist ambition for independence at any cost will see her avoid facing up to such a conundrum until it actually happens.Keith Howell, West Linton.THE four questions to Nicola Sturgeon in Mark Smithrsquos column go a long way to identying what doesnrsquot work with her approach to major constitutional issues in. As long as elections and referendums are based on first-past-the-post , the results will be what he describes rather too gently as ldquoan inaccurate reflection of opinion.The fundamental deficiency is that FPTP does not result in a spread of opinion in the so-called representatives which reflects the true wishes of the electorate as a whole. The votes of the PR-elected Scottish Parliament MSPs may seem more representative than FPTP, but bear in mind that  per cent of them are elected by FPTP in any case and the voters have no way of influencing the opinions or actions of the remaining list MSPs.It doesnrsquot need to be this way. There is already a clear majority in the Scottish Parliament for the Single Transferable Vote and one has to question why it has not already been enacted. Mr Smith might consider adding that to his questions. I hope he gets some answers, as I havenrsquot.Thomas GF Gray, Lenzie.STUART Waitonis right to highlight how elitism can be a downfall of a political party. However, to claim the stance of a Scottish-based party wishing to block a Brexit that the people of Scotland rejected at the ballot box during the  referendum was an ldquoanti-democratic rsquo smacks of another kind of elitism, one the Scottish people rejected on December  as it slowly wakes up to how the UK is not the vehicle in which to invest its future.The ided, uneven, dis-United Kingdom allows such views to fester, but it is this undemocratic straitjacket that the Scots find themselves in that will likely halt the SNP ision he evidently craves, until after independence, when it would not be unsurprising as his article alludes to, that some movement to other or new parties could occur.Iain Stewart, Carnoustie.ITrsquoS many years since Britannia ruled the waves, or, indeed, the air.With so much of this countryrsquos land, assets and economy under foreign ownership or control, it is little wonder that one seldom hears the use of the words lsquoGreat Britainrsquo to describe the nation.Now, with the political rhetoric employed on either side of Hadrianrsquos Wall, the accuracy of the title ldquoUnited Kingdom must be open to question. Perhaps it is time to settle for the simpler description of ldquoThe British Isles.Malcolm Allan, Bishopbriggs..Read more: Happy Christmas First Minister ndash here are some questions I think you should answer

title: staffs-sake-put-end-boxing-day-sales
story: When I worked in a city centre coffee shop, Boxing Day would begin with a glut of weary women pouring through our glass double doors not long after wed opened, laden with plump red bag after plump red bag from the Next Boxing Day sale.It started at what time  am  You started queueing at WHAT time  am  For clothes  The first time I came across it my mind was boggled. Could. Not. Compute.After the slew of early morning shoppers, it would be relatively calm as there wasnt an awful lot to come into the city for.New Years Day, too, would be eerie on the way into work as every other shop front was shuttered. By lunchtime we would be jam packed with stragglers who had come into the city centre for a look around only to find the place a ghost town. Mostly it was tourists, holiday makers who didnt realise the entire country was also on holiday.Now, in the city centre, youre spoiled for choice on New Years Day. No need to stay home when you can head into town.My memory might be playing tricks, but around that time, Im sure, Next was a one-off for its early opening hour, which was why the sale created such a legion of annual fans. Not so now.This year Matalan advertised am opening hours for some of its stores. Yesterday at the Intu Victoria Centre in Nottingham, shoppers queued from am, their Christmas dinners still halfway along their alimentary canals. Thats barely enough time to have digested the clfhanger from the Gavin and Stacey Christmas special before heading to the shops.Marks and Spencer got in ahead of the crowd by starting its online sale at pm on Christmas Day.And this is where the annual handwringing about gross consumerism begins but now we have an added tension - the environmental impact.Of course weve long known that consumerism has a negative environmental impact but this year it cant be ignored, Greta Thunberg has made sure of that.As Australian bushfires rage out of control, as children strike for climate action and as Donald Trump ties himself in knots over what wind is or isnt, we simply cant justy the unfettered desire for stuff that washes over us come Christmas time.Yet, as the planet is dying, so too is the high street.This year Scotland has seen some of the worst sales figures on record with store after store folding and hundreds of jobs being made redundant. Sales yesterday were expected to fall by . per cent on last year in real le shops, although online sales were expected to rise by  per cent.Boxing Day, for many retailers, remains the busiest in the calendar year and, against such bleak trading conditions, who can grudge them it Not everyone making the journey to the high street will be buying an entirely unnecessary set of hair straighteners to replace the nigh-on identical set of hair straighteners they bought last year. Not everyone will be buying their seventh pair of boyfriend jeans, each pair imperceptibly dferent from the last.Some people will be buying important household items that theyve waited all year to pick up, say. Or treating themselves to an item they otherwise couldnt afford. Something they might not "need" but that makes them feel better.Its not fair or reasonable to tar all frantic shoppers with one brush.As long as people are making justiable choices - without kidding themselves over what they want and what they need - then fine.For once we could perhaps look to Trump as a positive example. I mean, sort of. Grudgingly and at a push. Asked on Christmas Eve what hed bought for his we, the US President said he had only bought her a Christmas card. Im sure it was the most beautul and bigliest card ever but still, when you have everything you could possibly need, a card is enough.Hopefully Melania saw it the same way and wasnt expecting diamonds on Christmas morning. Still, Im quite sure shes used to being disappointed by her husband.Friends, this year for the first time, stepped back from gt buying. One of my friends doesnt want presents now she has children one feels we are too old for Christmas gts another feels the time of year is too stressful and so wanted to cut out the added pressure of buying presents.I love giving and receiving gts with friends because I feel its a way of showing thought and care. Yet I cant quibble with any of my now non-gting buying friends because, ultimately, I have everything I need and I fret over my environmental impact.Among the annual conversation about how much is too much, we often forget the other people at the heart of our consumer decisions - the retail staff who are giving up festive time with loved ones to facilitate our shopping habits.Of course, theres a flip side there too. Some will appreciate being able to earn double time, particularly at the most wonderfully expensive time of year. Others wont celebrate Christmas others might be lonely at the holiday season and enjoy being at work.Yet, do we really need to have retail staff on hand to serve us at am  We dont, of course not. Christmas is as much a time to relax, pause, take stock. We have whittled this down to one shop-free day, meaning retail workers have to sacrice this precious lull to folk can benefit from  per cent off a bath bomb.We must cut down on our spending habits. The high street will need to change and adapt as this happens.But for now, couldnt the Boxing Day sales wait until December  An extra day to reflect might even make people stop to think about what they are consuming and why.

title: boldly-go-mission-sell-science-school-girls-help-sci-fi
story: Dr Erin Macdonald is an astrophysicist and aerospace engineer who ldquoexplains the universe through popular sci-fi TV shows and films.She has made a Sound Tracks podcast for the University of Glasgow ndash where she gained her PhD ndash and is planning to take her fresh approach to science, technology, engineering and mathematicssubjects into Scottish schools.ldquoA lot of young people ndash particularly girls ndash are put off physics and maths, butyou explain theories in terms of what is and isnrsquot possible in films such as Star Wars, you can get through to them and hook their interest, said Dr Macdonald, who consults with science-fiction writers in Los Angeles, where she lives.Science fiction first drew her into the field of astrophysics when she watched Gillian Andersonrsquos character Dana Scully, an FBI agent with a degree in astrophysics.ldquoAt high school I was interested in robotics and technology but Irsquod never heard of astrophysics until I watched The X-Files, added Dr Macdonald, who studied at the University of Colorado before moving to the University of Glasgow. She now works with the team at the university researching gravitational waves, providing important insights into the origins of the universe, black holes, supernovae, gamma-ray bursts and neutron stars.ldquoDana Scully was the coolest person Irsquod ever seen and all I wanted to do was become her so I could use science to solve problems and fight aliens.ldquoI came to Star Trek later in college and Captain Janeway in Voyager kept me going through graduate school.While science fiction is not short of these strong female leads, Dr Macdonald found that real-le science is still a male-dominated field.ldquoAs a first-year undergraduate, my physics class was made up of around  per cent of women but, by the time I reached the final year, there were only  people in the class and one other woman.She first realised she could encourage others like herself into science through her love of popular culture when she started teaching in community college.ldquoI made a comparison to Star Wars and the whole class perked up.ldquoSo much of science, like quantum physics, is foreign to most people but when you can compare it to a familiar TV show or film you can help them understand.ldquoI started giving talks at sci-fi conventions, sharing my passion for the lsquoscience of science fictionrsquo.ldquoTherersquos a huge audience of people who have always loved science but never went into it, and who take any opportunity to learn more.ldquoLinking it to their favourite fandoms gives an anchor for references and makes it seem a little more accessible.ldquoI explain what can and canrsquot work in real science by exploring sci-fi devices such as travelling faster than the speed of light with a warp drive.ldquoAnd I use the Star Trek transporter to explain the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, which states we can never know the exact position and momentum of particles.ldquoThis rule makes a real-world transporter scientically impossible but the writers of Star Trek were clearly aware of this as there is a component in the transporter called a Heisenberg Compensator, said Dr Macdonald, who has an Audible Series, The Science of Sci-Fi, and a YouTube series, Dr Erin Explains the Universe.ldquoPeople teaching physics, maths and astronomy sometimes donrsquot know how to teach it ndash they know how it works but donrsquot understand how to communicate their knowledge in a relatable, accessible way, added Dr Macdonald, who sports tattoos of emc, Einsteinrsquos Theory of Relativity, and ldquoLive Long and Prosper in Vulcan script.Now she is planning ato Scotland to visit primary and secondary schools.ldquoI get kids coming up to me after my talks asking how they can get into science.ldquoI think popular science communicators play an important role in encouraging youngsters into STEM.ldquoAnd therersquos no doubt that dramas like The X-Files, Star Trek, Star Wars and The Big Bang Theory help make these subjects more attractive and less nerdy.

title: dunblane-teacher-fund-helps-school-arts
story: Now the memory of teacher Gwen Mayor lives on thanks to a charity in her name supporting arts, culture, music or sport in Scottish primary schools.The Gwen Mayor Trust, which was set up by the Educational Institute of Scotland after the shooting, has announced funding for  projects across Scotland.Schemes include a tone chimes musical project in Orkney, a healthy eating project in Dumfriesshire, a Scots language project in South Ayrshire and an inclusive play projectin Aberdeen.EIS general secretary Larry Flanagan said: ldquoThe Gwen Mayor Trust continues to support a wide range of wonderful projects in primary schools theand breadth of Scotland.ldquoThe EIS, and everyone associated with the trust, is extremely proud that the trustrsquos funding has benefited so many school communities and somany young people over the years.ldquoThe work of the trust in supporting arts, music, cultural and sporting projects across Scotland continues to be a fitting tribute to the memoryof Dunblane Primary School teacher Gwen Mayor.Mrs Mayorrsquos daughter and a former colleague from Dunblane Primary School are trustees to the fund, and all primary schools across Scotland are eligible to apply for funding from the trust.Since the trust first started awarding grants years ago, hundreds of primary schools and many thousands of young people have benefited through the support of the Gwen Mayor Trust.Mrs Mayor died alongside  of her primary one pupils at Dunblane Primary with lone gunman Thomas Hamilton launched an attack the schoolrsquos gymnasium.
